I was a bit hesitant on getting this game. Played Chivalry 1 in the past and had fun times with it. I bought this game about a 1-2 years after release. Gotta say it's a fun experience... Like you can hop on and play for 15min and have fun, or play for 2hrs and will still have a fun satisfying experience. 

This is a fighting game at it's core. You can button mash, but it's best to learn the cadences/combos. You can ride on horses, use enemy ballistas/siege weapons, and decapitating body parts always satisfying. The chaos in large battles is to be admired which comes with unique objectives. They have group 3v3, and your traditional 1v1. There is a tutorial and bot-only modes for practice.

Poor ranking/matchmaking filters leading to missed opportunities in E-sports. There can be lag at times like some reviews have mentioned, however it wasn't too overbearing. I have only ran this game on WiFi so.. 

You can customize your units, voices, gender, etc. However don't expect anything as detailed as The Sims. There is incentive to play longer and unlock new skins. DLC and seasonal updates seem to keep content fresh. However there isn't enough initiatives in their competitive space.

Missed naval combat scenarios? Potentially in a sequel.

Great game, not so great developers. I liked this game so much I bought it again and started playing it here on Steam (I have ~600 hours on the Epic games store version, which was released like a year before the steam release). They also talked about letting us transfer progress when it was finally released on steam (but didn't, and never talked about it again, a theme veteran players are all too familiar with)

Torn Banner really fumbled the bag on this one and lost so much potential in this game. Best thing they could do now is permanently drop the price, allow private servers, and let the modding community take over. Mods will create new life in this dead boi, Helm's Deep with Chivalry 2 combat, imagine! Ranked servers, new player friendly servers, etc. 

As of now the new player experience* is to skip the tutorial and join 64 player team objective (against players with 100s-1000s of hours played) where you go 2-20 KD every game for a few hours then uninstall. I love this game, and I hate seeing players have such a terrible experience and quit without fully unlocking the potential to have fun, because once you have full control over your game, the opportunities to have fun are endless. But I also know a lot of OG players who have quit (and I miss them, dearly).
This game is a sandbox for creativity and fun, all the templates are there, the mechanics are there, it just needs to have it's gate open by the devs. Give us private servers and mod support and you'll see a second wind in this gem whose potential is being stunted. 

*Perfect example is this free to play weekend (12/9/23), every time it's on sale or free to play - dormant toxic level 800-1000s come back and stomp the new players. I only see these mediocre players come back when it's a free weekend or something happened where there's an influx of new players. Really sad to see, because they gatekeep the hell out of the new player experience.

No option to join matches at the start; Join most matches late; Can't choose which map you want; Can't choose which team you want.
If you do happen to randomly join a match & team you want to play on, there's a good chance you'll get auto-team switched midway through - which also ruins the game.

Apparently the devs think that giving players absolutely no choice makes it 'balanced & fun', when in reality it just means you'll rarely ever get a full game on a map & team you want and so it's mostly just annoying, boring, and match results & all stats are utterly meaningless as a result.
(who cares if that random team you didn't want to join, loses on that random map you didn't want to play on)

Most of my 'game time' is leaving it idle while doing other things, looking sometimes to see if it'll ever join a map & team I want. 
There's no point trying to find another match after it's randomly joined you into one because most of the time it just rejoins you back into the same match you've already left, which just wastes more time.

I once wanted a single match on Lionspire map as Attackers from the start -  There are only a few maps & 2 teams but I had to leave the game idle for about 8 hours before I was able to play that 1 short game.

As of writing this I am level 680 with 700+ hours with a deep understanding of the game and its mechanics. First of, the pros. The combat is satisfying and intuitive and the overall flow of the game is fun and fast-paced. Most of the maps are fun and engaging. The interactions you have in-game can be funny. Sadly that's where the positives end.

The community is divided with Torn Banner releasing sparse updates each year (around 2-3 updates if we're lucky) and each update doesn't offer much content, maybe a weapon or two or a map but that's about it. The battle passes are pitiful with only 40 levels each which can be completed in a matter of days. Team balance is FUBAR and some maps favour either attackers or defenders so you will often get steam rolled. There's no ranked mode so comp is pretty much dead aside for clans on Discord who host private duel servers. 

That being said, this game is a lot of fun for fans of melee games like Mordhau, Chiv 1, Mount & Blade etc. but there is a good chance that new players to the genre may get turned off by some of the mechanics and general bs of the game. Would recommend checking out tho.

Hello,

Read this before purchasing the game.

After more than 100 hours in this game, I have something to say. I have never written negative reviews about games, but this time it's just the height of absurdity in every damn parameter.

Let's start with the main issue:
The developers couldn't care less about their own product; the release of buggy patches happens constantly. Take the latest one, 2.9, for example. I want to point out that in this "magnificent masterpiece" of indifference, patches come out once every !!!six!!! months, assuming the development team hasn't gone crazy on cocaine. !ATTENTION, ONCE ONLY IN SIX F***ING MONTHS! They added only new, broken weapons that don't correspond to their characteristics. They simply repurposed an existing crossbow into the new weapon and didn't test its feature, which it was supposed to have.

I find myself yelling "WHAT?!" while playing this game.  Like, a lot.  Counters that somehow weren't counters.  Attacks going straight through blocks.  Parries that work about half the time.  Shorter weapons hitting me when I somehow whiffed them.  Teammates that down me in the middle of the fight of my life by swinging right into my back, missing the enemy, and then dying after killing me.  

However, this game also has given me some crazy good moments.  Winning 5V1s, holding the line with a group of randoms, storming passed dug-in defenders, winning amazing duels, and butchering gangs of Mason dogs for the glory of Agatha.  The drip is top-notch (except for Tenosia), battlecries are awesome, and its overall a good time. 

However again, there are many glitches, bugs, stutters, etc.  Torn Banner also seems to break the game after every update, with hit reg (among other things) getting bad and staying broken for a while.  Still, I love this game.  I am level 170 on PS5 and level 130 here on PC, my new home for Chiv.  

I can't put this game down for long.  It beats me, bruises me, and mentally harms me, but I keep coming back.  

I love Chiv 2 with all my heart, even when she doesn't love me.

stab good

The is NO skill based matchmaking.

Two people can ruin entire maps by going engineer on defence.

There is no counter to Engineers.

The siege crossbow is bugged, dealing no damage to buildings (It wouldn't matter regardless, based on where Engi walls are placed per map. That and; other players + terrain + layout means they can't hit anyway)

Equaliser weapons exist, making the Armour / HP of Knight and Footman entirely useless. (Blunt / Axe weapons)

Meta weapons are ungodly strong compared to others, if they where used more the game would suck: Dane Axe, War Club, Pole Hammer (Special can 1 shot footman with a head-hit btw), Warhammer and Highlander (If you know how to animation exploit / time crouch spam, it's not hard), War Bow, Greatsword, Mace / Morning Star.

10/10 would vs console players and top scoreboards with the worst weapon, a shovel, again.

P.S. Season passes don't expire as well. Say what you want, but this games monetisation and matchmaking (No SBMM) are the gold standard of a good video game, despite balance and map issues. I mostly play 64 player modes, only ran into a single hacker who got banned mid game, no idea where those complaints come from as someone with over 200 hours.

Games bloody good fun once you learn not to die every time you dare attack established players. Interactions with fellow players be it your team mates or the enemy can be hilarious at times, it's also one of those games where combat can absolutely boil your piss one moment (Archers!), and then in the next have you howling with laughter when vengeance is served.

To start with find a class you like and really stick with it, combat swing/parry/duck/counter timing is everything, just swinging wildly will get you no where other than dead. Classes are varied, and you unlock weapons etc via in-game rank/currency earned through combat. Maps range from large to small and vary greatly. 

Maximum player count is 64, chat spam's auto blocked, and servers feature a vote kick system which is not easily abused. You can party up with Steam friends, and game features cross play so you can enjoy battering the console plebs, although the majority still seem to be PC players.

Big negative is the lack of in game voice mic communication support, so good job the character voice emote wheels are expansive and often funny to use in the given moment. Can always use discord, but for those not in your group; once you learn the voice lines for each class it becomes easy to get across what you want to convey to others around you.

Game runs well on older PC hardware, UK/EU servers are mostly very good; joining them is trouble free, along with good pings (Mine fluctuates between 1 and 4ms on all EU/UK servers!).
Very fun when it doesn't lag. Good ping doesn't mean servers won't lag. But when it works, it's fun to run brainlessly and hack some enemies. Beware annoying archers

It is now common for server desync to kill you upwards of 10 times per game with your attacks phasing through people (ghosts?) and stuttering issues. Not to mention the issues that arise while trying to connect to games.

But if you're looking to get drunk and cleave through people aimlessly, then you'll probably still find some enjoyment here.

Game is great, and lives up to the Chiv 1, and even superseeds it in many ways.
Just want to voice how I'm disappointed with the direction of where the game is going.

-THE MAPS-
While game has a _ton_ of maps, you'll play like 5.
For some reason certain maps are just exclusive to one 64 player queue, which offers more hectic / less controlled gamplay (tl;dr - too much zerg)

-THE UPDATES-
previous 3 updates brought issues one after the other:
1. straight out broken map (Winter assault), with below 30 fps for even high-end PCs (took months to fix)
2. map that looked ugly af with either lowres textures or texture loading issues? (it still does look ugly)
3. and then the last one - Reclamation update brought map with 1/3rd of  content/playtime.

All issues are constantly brought up, there is a communication with community/playtests, but at the end of the day it feels like nothing changes.

-THE MOD SUPPORT-
This was talked about, before the release of the game. Chiv 1 lived so long not because it had 100 maps, but because modders made dosens of maps and gamemodes. Some maps even became part of the official queue.

TL;DR
This game gets 2-3 maps per year, with performance issues that take months to fix.
It just not enough variaion for a long-term enjoyment

[i]Chivalry 2 brought me back to the days of my fascination with medieval history. The clang of swords, the rush of charging into battle – it's all here. [/i]

[h1][b] 📝Story/Plot without spoilers:[/b][/h1]
[table][tr][td] 🔸 Chivalry 2 doesn't have a traditional narrative, but it's set in a fictional medieval world where two factions, the Agatha Knights and the Mason Order, are locked in a perpetual war. The game's focus is on delivering an authentic medieval warfare experience, where each battle tells its own story of bravery, strategy, and, of course, chaos.
[/td][/tr][/table]

[h1][b]🎮Gameplay:[/b][/h1]
[table][tr][td] 🔸 Chivalry 2 is not just a game; it's a plunge into the heart of medieval warfare. The combat system is a complex dance of strikes, blocks, and feints, requiring both skill and strategy. Players can choose from a range of classes, each with its own unique weapons and playstyles. Whether you're wielding a massive two-handed sword as a Knight or picking off enemies from a distance as an Archer, the game offers a diverse combat experience.

------🔹 The real thrill of Chivalry 2 lies in its large-scale battles. These 64-player skirmishes are chaotic, intense, and utterly captivating. You'll find yourself storming castles, laying siege to fortresses, and engaging in brutal melee combat. The game's objective-based modes add a layer of strategy, where you're not just fighting for kills but also working with your team to achieve specific goals.

------🔹 The combat mechanics are deep and nuanced. Timing and precision are key, as is understanding the strengths and weaknesses of your chosen class and weapons. The game rewards skillful play, and there's a real sense of progression as you learn to parry effectively, time your counter-attacks, and use the environment to your advantage.

------🔹 Chivalry 2 also excels in its attention to detail. The battlefields are dynamic, with destructible environments and interactive elements that can turn the tide of battle. Siege weapons like catapults and ballistae add another layer of depth, allowing for devastating attacks but requiring coordination and protection.

------🔹 The game's combat is brutal and unforgiving, but also exhilarating. The satisfaction of landing a well-timed strike or successfully leading a charge against overwhelming odds is unmatched. The game also injects a sense of humor and absurdity into the proceedings, with over-the-top voice lines and scenarios that lighten the mood amidst the carnage.

------🔹 For those looking to refine their skills, the game offers a tutorial and practice modes. These are invaluable resources for newcomers, as they provide a safe space to get to grips with the game's mechanics without the pressure of real combat.

[/td][/tr][/table]

[h1][b]📷Graphics:[/b][/h1]
[table][tr][td] 🔸 The graphics in Chivalry 2 are a feast for the eyes. The attention to detail in the armor, weapons, blood and environments is commendable. The game does a fantastic job of immersing players in a medieval world, with each map offering a visually distinct and historically inspired setting.
[/td][/tr][/table]

[h1][b]📝Main Pros and Cons:[/b][/h1]

[b] 🟩Pros-[/b]

	+Deep and rewarding combat system.
	+Visually stunning medieval environments.
	+Dynamic and immersive audio.
	+Great variety in classes and weapons.

[b] 🟥Cons-[/b]

	-Steep learning curve for beginners.
	-Price might be a barrier for casual gamers.

[h1][b]🏷️Tips for beginners:[/b][/h1]
[table][tr][td] 🔸 Start by mastering one class and weapon type. Understanding the basics of blocking, parrying, and attacking is crucial. Don't be afraid to jump into the fray – learning by doing is key in Chivalry 2. Also, teamwork is essential, so communicate and strategize with your teammates for a more fulfilling experience.
[/td][/tr][/table]

[h1][b]✉️Miscellaneous Information:[/b][/h1]
[b]Customization-[/b]
The game excels in customization, allowing players to personalize their warriors' appearance and gear. This includes a variety of armor styles, colors, and weapons, each affecting gameplay. Progress unlocks new abilities and equipment, offering strategic depth and personal expression on the battlefield.


[h1][b]😇Verdict:[/b][/h1]
[table][tr][td] 🔸 Chivalry 2 is a must-play for anyone who dreams of stepping into a medieval battlefield. The game does an excellent job of balancing realism with fun, offering an experience that is both challenging and rewarding. It's a game that will keep you coming back for more, whether to improve your skills or just to enjoy the thrill of battle. Highly recommended for fans of the genre!
[/td][/tr][/table]

*UPDATE*
I still would not recommend this game to Chivalry 1 players, UNLESS you are simply totally desperate to fill the slasher niche (the reason I have been playing). Why do I say that? Well, there is always Mordhau, but Mordhau's maps and the domination game type are simply dry. Chivalry 2 does deliver episodic, team objective maps. That's it.

The issue being, the maps and gameplay are inferior in every way to Chivalry 1. I feel this is because they were designed with the clusterfug gameplay of 60+ players in mind. Still, TO is better than no TO. The 40-player gametype is passable, but the maps are just not designed around a lower player count.

The combat is openly catered towards noobs. It's explicitly designed around giving  casual players the ability to acquire kills and defend themselves with little to no investment or skill. What this does is serve as a detriment to gameplay at the skill cap. High level dueling eventually boils down to a more rhythm-esque experience like Sekiro (countering and playing the initiative/stamina game). Getting more attuned to the combat feels like becoming more and more of an automaton/machine, looking for patterns in the ivy, without much of the human element that made Chivalry 1 awesome. My question is why? The experience is inferior in every way to the more hardcore nature of Chivalry 1 where deception, mental fortitude, timing, mechanical skill, all blended into the combat. 

Like any genre, casualization has infected the melee slasher. Here's hoping something comes along that's worth taking seriously.
__________________
Over 500 hours played in Chivalry 1. Chivalry 1 is one of my favorite games.
I already tried the game back at Epic release but decided to try here as well as a year or so has passed.
I’ll be frank with this review. In all, if you are looking for more of Chivalry 1, look not here. Chivalry 2 feels like a “dumbed down” version of its predecessor. Slow, methodical combat with map design and speed that allowed plentiful avenues for single combat are replaced with generally chaotic clusters and, ultimately, blob warfare. Mordhau also largely suffered this disease. I can understand the design philosophy: create chaos for cinematic effect and for players to have a more accessible, friendly experience, where easy kills are plentiful and generate dopamine. Sadly, the game is very conducive to mindless, arcadey fun. The game really evokes no competitive thrill. There appears to be no private server hosting capability either (or simply no one is hosting them) so it’s not even an option to reduce players on the map. Former competitive games modes that thrived in Chivalry 1 (such as LTS) exist but are largely empty.
I’ll pass.

This game is pretty great; it focuses on the whole casual aspect of what Mordhau wanted to be and excels at putting players in the perspective of warring nations in strife. The story as a whole is easy to pick up and completely optional for those who want or do not want to hear any. However, due to the fact that this game is mostly casual, the combat isn't too hard to pick up. There will be god-gamer sweats in most lobbies, but unlike in Mordhau, it's still playable to an enjoyable degree.

Unfortunately, archers exist in this game, and they are as annoying as you would expect in a medieval melee-focused game. However, you have plenty of options to counter arrows coming your way, either by dodging irrationally, using any type of shield, or not even going into view of archers.

There is music, and it plays at pivotal moments of battle. Pushing through a gate to fight a duke with only a few minutes left, an intense attrition fight; pushing back attackers from lighting a boat to explode, along with many, many other locations that trigger music to play.

Most, if not all, weapons are useful in some degree; however, there are two major weapons that newcomers stick to: the Dane Axe and the Messer. Now, these weapons aren't horrible; in fact, they're typically the best weapons in the game. However, it feeds newer players into the bad habit of constantly swinging without a thought. Though there are better alternatives in the game. The halberd and longsword make great alternatives if you wish to get out of the constant wall that would be set up against decent players.

Lastly, there are bugs in this game. Either with incompetent servers, rarely cheaters (on my end), or plenty of other problems that haven't been updated since the release. Though they start to show their ugly heads after awhile, in this amazing game that I and many others have fallen in love with. Unfortunately, with how Torn Banner has been treating the game with mediocre updates, a lot of folks have been in the downward spiral of what even Team Fortress 2's lack of critical updates has brought. Even in Chivalry 2, it's not the greatest sight. Though the game is still well made, it is definitely worth your money.

This is a hard review to write for me, because I've spent so much time in this game and I don't want it to mean nothing. I'll start by saying that this game is very good AT FIRST. I mean as a fresh install it's very enjoyable, especially when you don't have a grasp of the mechanics like a seasoned veteran of the game or like a mordhau vet switching over would. It's just a goofy medieval cluster fuck, and the majority of the community reflects that. And don't get me wrong, it can and will be fun for most people, even me. 
However, the game itself is broken in a bad way. I think most people will start to notice the flaws once they hit around level 100, but the game's still fun at that level, you're experienced enough to win a lot of fights and even sometimes take out a level 700+ player, but you will still be oblivious to the overall broken nature of the game. But once you really get into the sauce you realize just how good we could have it. Regularly hits will desync, hitreg will feel off, you'll pull off a sick counter slash and have the bright blue shield guiding your strike into a group of 5 grizzled assailants and as that dopamine is about to enter your brain, your counter gets counterfeited, their slash will just slice through your counter, as if god himself is punishing you for a crime you never committed. You will cleave someone in two with an overhead, only to see they actually didn't get hit by it even though you saw on your very own screen the sword on top of the enemy. And honestly if it was just issues like that on a rare/uncommon level, i would still recommend the game. But no dear reader, it doesn't end there. The developers of this game are grossly incompetent at their best and downright spiteful at their worst, and I say this as someone who has met and played with some of the devs before. The developers at torn banner have neglected this game like an unwanted child.
The new update is laughably bad, with even worse desync and hitreg issues than before, along with a map that's so bad I can't begin to understand how it got released the way it is. I'll go ahead and touch on the map issues first. Basically, the map is far too short, and it's far too busy. The first half of the map features rocks and slopes that are almost impossible to navigate without getting stuck on every pebble, which destroys the flow of any fight and makes using footwork effectively a pipe dream. There's also the terribly small choke points and the flow of the map feels like it was designed to make what should be 1-2 objectives into 4. Along with the final objective being both open but too claustrophobic and the entire map is far too easy for the heavily stacked attack teams to win. Oh yeah, I should bring up just how bad team stacking is in this game.
Team stacking is by far one of the most prevelant issues i've noticed. It feels like the community at large is silent about it these days, but almost every single game is a stacked one-sided match, usually with the attacking team being stacked the hardest. I have had dozens upon dozens of games end up with the attacking team having several level 100+ players with a few 500+ "good" players, and the defending team having a handful of okay players and maybe one actual good player. And as one of the good players I take it upon myself to try to help out the underdog teams, to keep it balanced. But what usually happens is I run into a fight with my team in a fresh respawn wave, and every single one of them die within 1-10 seconds, and I'm left on my own or with 1-2 teammates (both of which are most likely walking directly in front of me, blocking my hits and feeding the enemy ripostes and counters) trying to claw our way back to victory. And when you're on the winning team, it's just a unfun shit stomp, rolling over a team of level 15 players who are probably questioning their recent purchase of this game. It's gotten to a point where I won't even queue up the main menu gamemodes because I feel like an asshole playing the stacked team, but I also cant have an enjoyable time on the losing team because I just can't trust them not to grief our team by feeding the enemy counters and ripostes and having very poor game sense. 
And before you ask, yes there is a competitive scene. But comp scene is very grassroots and has been neglected by the devs for so long. There aren't private servers (they've promised they'd add them several times but still have yet to) and so the only way to hold tournaments is by either getting mod support or a password server, both of which involve contacting the chiv mod mail, which they rarely respond to. I mean there's only like 1-2 mods who even care about competitive (funk and cody), and while I and many others appreciate what they do (seriously thank you guys) it just isn't enough. The devs themselves don't actually do anything for the competitive community, prizepools on tournaments are very small and often player funded, and the devs are known to just randomly cut off their support from tournaments, causing confusion and anger within the community. What most clans have to do to be able to get practice in for matches or if the mods don't have time or don't reply to the mod mail, is they end up having to take over a empty dedicated server in the server browser, and they're forced to votekick anyone who joins. Which just sucks for everyone involved. It takes time out of the competitive player's matches to have to vote kick people, and it's really unfair to these people getting kicked, especially console players who don't have chat and aren't aware of what is happening. It causes a rift in the community with a lot of people (reddit mostly) hating on high level players from clans for kicking and being "toxic" when all they want to do is just play this game at a competitive level. 
There's a few more things I want to mention before I close off this review, like how almost every update has broken the game more. I can't tell you how many times they've broken vote kicking with each new update (bridgetown and the one update prior come to mind), which ruins duel servers every single time it happens. Oh and speaking of duel servers, I want to mention how fucked it is that duel servers are just full of people RDMing every single match, mostly due to console players not having chat. So if a console player joins, aside from the name of the server which they only see for like 1 second before they join, they don't know that it's a duel server, and I don't blame them. It literally says "free for all" at the top of the screen, it doesn't say "duels" or anything, and without access to chat on console they cant be told its a duel server. And even if you are a console player who knows that it's duels, you still can't read chat, so you can't even read chat to get context on stuff like a vote kick. 

There's just so many small quirks and bad will that has been building up over the years, to the point now where a lot of the community (casual and comp) are pretty sick of torn banner and just wish the game was handled by a different developer or finally given the love it deserves. Because the core gameplay loop of this game is something really special and good, and if it wasn't for all the constant stuttering and hitreg issues, and the badwill they've built, it would be a great game. I mean I didn't even mention until now how bad the ping in servers is, and how you can have a stable internet connection with 20 ping normally, but you will still see your ping spike up to 100+ constantly. Plus I mean it takes them 7 months to put out a small update and it's been like that since the game came out. So much of the comp community is burnt out at this point and honestly I am too, if it wasn't for community legends like Sun God putting out stuff like MFL every other week this game would be so dead. I mean the game is dead actually, like unless you're playing at peak hours. So the TL:DR is get the game on sale otherwise don't bother.

it's fun and the most fun hack and slash FPS out there, the problem is that it's a competitive FPS with a high skill ceiling. now that the game has been out for a long time it's mostly sweaty teenage/neet veterans playing now even after the new patch, so new players who don't have lots of experience in similar games are getting BTFO'd and from what i'm seeing most people aren't trying to help onboard them. so only get if you have a lot of chiv 1 or mordhau experience.

Servers have gotten really bad. Even with with low ping <20ms, a lot of your attacks and blocks will be ignored by the server, and you'll also experience a lot of network stutters where your game will freeze and you and your opponents will be teleported into different positions. There's also no option to have dedicated/community servers, so this game is pretty much unplayable at the moment -- it took them half a year to release a half finished map, so I doubt they'll fix the game anytime soon.

I prefer Mordhau.

Hold block makes 1vX feel less impressive.  Everyone having dash is dumb.  If you think two people endlessly morphing eachother is good duel gameplay, you found your game.

I played a lot of Chiv 1 and was hype for Chiv 2 as there were things I missed.  I liked the clear class definitions in chiv.  something 2 has destroyed as the mixture of roles is blurred as every class has access to everything making classes pointless.

I also missed how you could tell who was on your team based on sound and voice lines.  This situational awareness meant chaotic frontlines were a bit less so.  Perhaps after playing longer, I would recognise all the voices in chiv 2 but I didn't notice much distinction between the factions and also found the identities given to Mason and Agatha jarring, as if we were playing a different game all these years.

Mordhau feels more alive, even though playercounts are slightly the other way.  Due to Mordhau players playing on community servers

Duelling in Chiv 2 is boring, everymap has some dumb cutscene on spawn and no auto healing.  And the opportunities for clowning are few and far between.  that gives the try-hard nature of duels a much needed lighter side and is a massive part of Mordhau.

Customisation UI is a chore, customisation in Mordhau is a joy.

Voice lines are kind of cringe, the performances and sound quality is good but something about the writing, everythings a bit tripe and watered down. 

The animations, frankly look janky. I don't mind it, it has it's own look that I would get with if everything else about the game was good.

So ok, you go the main TO queue where you might get 6 other PC players who know what they are doing and 40 players that at first I thought were bots, but now I guess are console players? I have 18 hours, years after launch and I can top score in the main TO... what's going on with your game?

An absolutely amazing game. I love the energy, the gameplay, the maps, and just the entire design of the game. Having people spawn as a wave? Brilliant idea that adds much needed structure to players' inclination towards holding W.

So why negative? Players are pretty toxic these days. I know my playtime isn't much, but I originally started on console, so my playtime is greater than this profile alone. As a day-one player, I feel the community has gotten worse overtime. I have installed and uninstalled this game 4 times since getting it on Steam. Entirely due to toxic behavior/chat.

It's not all bad mind you. Sometimes players will join me in my attempts to liven things up. They'll defend my positive words and sometimes join me. Usually though I'll congratulate the enemy on a good push, or my allies with their sudden rally against the enemy, only to be told "shut up nerd".

It's not the most toxic community. Dead by Daylight is much worse, or last I checked it was. But I find myself hesitant to reinstall to try out the newest update. Maybe I've grown softer the older I get. Maybe I just need thicker skin. But I miss playing this game. Don't miss the community.

Hit detection is absolute dog sh*t, and the mechanics only want to work some of the time.
The tutorial tells you that you have to actually block an attack with your weapon, as in the two need to make contact, but more often than not I some how have my attack blocked by an enemy that isn't even facing toward me. I can literally see my weapon about to make contact with their back, but then it's just magically deflected because the enemy was blocking a different attack from someone else.

Team stacking is also a thing, really good players will join the attacking side and steam roll the defense in about 80% of the matches.

And don't bother trying to help your teammates, they usually get in the way of your attacks or they just run off and leave you to fight to 2+ enemies you just tried to help them with.

Almost forgot, the weapons aren't balanced either. Some how a GIANT 2-hander can be swung faster than a small hatchet.

Chivalry 1 was more fun. This game feels more cinematic than playable. They have taken every wrong decision at every point of the game. It irritates you.

- Inertia is considered when you run and change directions with arrow keys but not when you turn with mouse? Someone can run around you faster than you can swing!
- Every spawn is on the blind side of the other teams spawn. You either slaughter poor players from their behind or get slaughtered from behind. There is no satisfaction. Just frustration.
- There is no sense of team balance at all in this game and it's deliberate.
- Weapon mechanics are just counter intuitive at this point.
- And why can't I hold my throwing weapon in hand at the cost of stamina like archers do? Why must I release just 1 second after drawing my throwing axe?
- And did you know you can block a thrown javelin when you are not actively looking at it? But for sword swings you must have the tip of the sword in your view to block it! Oh and you can block an arrow as well but it still hits you although at 50% damage only.
- And what's with going down on all fours when you take damage? When do you die and when do you start to crawl. And why can't you bring your self up when no one is around? But you can bring yourself up if you punch enemies' calves 2 times! Your teammate must revive your from crawling. This is the forced teamwork they make you do but reduced the team damage on swings so everyone is swinging around. In Chivalry 1 you had to be careful of your teammates and use stab/slash instead of swinging around hitting everyone. They take out the natural teamwork from game and push on an artificial one.
- Cheap servers. They can't handle 64 players at a time.
- And bugs! It looks like there is just one person working on every aspect of the game. If that is the case, we're proud of you Bob but you need to throw in your towel at some point.
- Matchmaking sucks, often times I get a server withing 2-3 seconds that's 250 ping away! I need to restart matchmaking twice thrice to get a server near me. Just give an option for maximum acceptable ping and let me wait till I get a spot on server near me.
- They do release new skins and micro-transactions instead of fixing issues. So you know where their priorities lie.

Chiv 2 is honestly one of the best games I have played. It actually captures that chaos and dynamic combat that one would hope for a game to achieve that is based on combat in the middle ages. 

At best, you feel like a legend on the field, landing top spot and driving the objective maps to victory. At worst you feel like you need to head back to dueling servers to get your technique up.

The game has immense potential, we could see the mechanics being used in different universes like LOTR or Starwars. Chiv really has a functionally unique combat system that makes even playing the same maps over and over again entertaining.

Though the dev team takes their time for updating the game, it is still always worth diving into and being patient for it to drop.

For new players or people thinking of getting the game, don't be discouraged by high level players steamrolling or people busting out fancy feints. Dive in head first, find your groove, earn your glory. There are toxic sweats but there are also good folks who will fight with you and teach you how to hold your own.

An incredibly unique, fun, and frenetic multiplayer experience, with some major caveats. Buy on sale.

Pros:
-accessible yet deep gameplay. I was able to deal damage and get enough points to be right in the middle of the leaderboards on my first games. Combat is intense and a clusterf--- in the best ways, and you'll be getting better almost always. however, ymmv. TTK is quick enough and spawning never takes more then 5 seconds.
-presentation. having battles start with a captain's rallying speech or a bit of lore is a really nice touch, and the lore isn't at all necessary to enjoyment--reminds me a lot of Titanfall in that regard. Graphics, voice acting, and sounds are also excellent.
-easy and vast customization and roleplay options, like communications wheels, armor sets, helmets, weapons, weapon skins, character faces, voices, hairstyles, accessories, etc. there are 4 factions, each with 4 customizeable base classes--Your Mason Knight can look different from your Mason Archer, but also look different from your Agathian Knight, etc. Plenty of humorous items and such as well.

cons:
-Price. 40 dollars is simply too much for a multiplayer-only game, no matter how high quality. 30 feels much more fair, with maybe 40+ being special edition pricing.
-lobbies can be WILDLY imbalanced, not to mention the fair amount of toxicity in chat that's par for the course in MP games.
-no private servers as far as i can tell, which also means no meaningful mod support
-not enough modes. I love the fact that most matches play out more like real-world sieges and field battles, but a set of more basic modes like CTF and some spins on TDM, like Free For All or Hardcore would be generously welcomed.
Very fun game and challenging to master. Solid 9/10, needs more content though and mod support.

This is the most genuine, pure unfiltered FUN I've had in a video game for the longest time ever.
Interactive environment, storytelling that occurs naturally from the gameplay, utterly inert of unfairness.
The battlefield team-work really comes to life here in a variety of beautiful maps. 
The only downside stems from the greatness of the unorthodox gamemodes, usually being a thematic part of an event.
The problem is that it is limited, and so the game has official, everstanding modes coupled with event-locked modes or simply modes that do not stay for ever.  These I find to be the highlight of the game, but also sieges.
Sieges are what differentiates this game from the likes of Mordhau. That game is a wretched game inhabited by smelly tryhards. No, in this game you do have skill ceiling but the combat feels much more fun. Duels are perhaps the weakest point of Chivalry, in comparison to Mordhau perhaps, however do not let yourself believe that this game lacks any complexity at all. It is simply different, and equally mechanical. Grab a spear as a castle defender and stab people when they try to jump from a siege tower. Grab a knife stuck in your teammate and throw it at someone. This game is fun.

Updating outdated review. Review was shortly after release.

This game is fun, mechanically straight forward and easy to pick up.
Unfortunately, this arena hack & slash genre doesn't seem to last long anymore.
You have your regular fans, and your diehard fans who love it whether it be this or mordhau, most of us spawning originally from Chivalry or M&B players. They just don't stay popular for long. Why, idk?

Well, swordplay is easy in this game, Rinse & repeat. Not much to offer, its objective based but still people play like its a deathmatch and just push forwards. It's fun, like I said, but only fun for so long.

I love the community here way over Mordhau though. Mordhau is ruined by moderators and gamers alike. This title atleast the big sweats aren't really that much competition. A lot less toxicity in chat, bc most people are too busy actually playing.

I don't game as much as i used to. I could easily be on sweat level, but being a casual (just hit 38) pro, I can still clock top leaderboards in servers w them where I am the odball out of all the level 200+ players at the top of the scores. Feels good, but when you're that used to the game, It's only fun for a few hours if that at a time.

Still, easy to pick up, over all more balanced classes, unlike mordhau which is heavily meta based (although you can do good with non meta weapons, its easy to abuse). Sure there are "drags and accells" intended to work a certain way, but the good thing here vs other places, they aren't gonna be dragging through you for twice the damage it's normally supposed to do. 

That shit is whack, and doesn't happen here. Every hit damage percentage is based on placement and how much power you put in to the charge. Combat is decent, arcade-y but overall enjoyable.

Unrelated but if I were to compare my experience bc there are people who would like to know this:

Mordhau- Solid game, swordplay is fun, more freedom to build what you want. mechanics easy to abuse though.trash community with trash moderators = completely ruined game. Dont care how good I feel about the game. They ruin the replayability. Also their servers suck ass. They only have like 2 dedicated servers per region at random times of the day for large modes. sucks donkey balls.

Chivalry 2: Easy out the box. forgiving stamina/block system(not time reaction based completely, there are bonuses to blocking at the right times though). Class leveling (and weapons) kinda sucks, but its not hard to level. you'll get good eventually. Matchmaking system makes joining larger servers easier, yet the community has shrunken since its release, game is best during peak timezones for certain regions. Not a lot of variety, but keeps it simple and doesn't overwhelm you so you can hop in and join the action. It was like this in Chivalry 1, so no big deal there I guess. 

Even though I favor Mordhau in freedom of combat and style, and the amount of things you can actually do given that type of system makes melee combat 10x better; Chivalry takes the cake in the end due to simplicity and easier to pick up and have fun in a few rounds. 

The moderators in Mordhau ruin that for you. They've banned dedicated players with thousands of hours from their community just because the moderator said so. Yeah, its bullshit. You don't run into that type of bullshit here which makes Chivalry automatically so much better. Also the non-existence of hundreds of meta mechanic abusers = 10x points for Chivalry. Mordhau dev's know it's a problem with some of their weapons, and they just don't fucking care LMFAO.

Oh, where do I even begin with Chivalry 2? Let me tell you, playing this game was like voluntarily subjecting myself to medieval torture. I'd rather face a horde of angry knights armed with foam noodles than endure another minute of this game.

First of all, the graphics. I've seen better medieval landscapes in children's finger paintings. The characters look like they were designed by a blindfolded toddler using Play-Doh. I half-expected the knights to start wobbling and collapsing under the weight of their own armor, which would have at least provided some unintentional entertainment.

And let's talk about the gameplay, or lack thereof. Fighting in Chivalry 2 feels like trying to juggle flaming swords while riding a unicycle on a tightrope over a pit of lava. The controls are about as responsive as a sloth on sedatives. I've seen more fluid movement in a slideshow of medieval stick figures. Trying to coordinate attacks is like herding cats – except the cats are armed with swords and have a personal vendetta against you.

Oh, and the sound design? It's like they hired a pack of howler monkeys and told them to bang on pots and pans to create the soundtrack. The voice acting is so cringe-worthy that I considered muting the game and just making up my own dialogue. I'm pretty sure I could come up with something more compelling, like "I am Sir Clumsy, the Knight Who Trips Over His Own Feet."

The game's community isn't any better. I've encountered more toxic players than a chemical waste dump. It's like every frustrated medieval history enthusiast crawled out of their basement, donned a suit of armor made of Doritos, and decided to take out their aggression on unsuspecting newcomers. If I wanted to be verbally abused by strangers, I'd log into a social media platform – at least there, I can hit the mute button.

In conclusion, playing Chivalry 2 was a medieval nightmare that I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy. If you enjoy frustration, terrible graphics, clunky controls, ear-piercing sounds, and a community that makes the Spanish Inquisition look like a tea party, then by all means, dive right in. As for me, I'll be uninstalling this travesty faster than you can say "bring back the plague." 2/10

Switching weapons takes multiple clicks of the button as does jump which doesn't sound like a big issue unless you are in one on one combat.  The mechanics of weapons are supposed to be realistic but basic rules of physics are regularly ignored. For instance a two handed weapon cannot accelerate to full steep instantly from the furthest back in its swing. Stepping into that swing should limit damage but does not. Arrows travel at about 1/2 the speed they should and I find targets often evade a shot even though the arrow  appears to go through them. 

Until they fix these issues don't bother with this game!

OK.... so after quite some time in this game, i'll start by saying this. Chivalry 2 WAS and i quote WAS a great game. Huge potential. But this is no more. DO NOT LISTEN TO THESE POSITIVE REVIEWS!!! Chiv has honestly hit rock bottom. at least in my opinion. Dueling servers are a joke, cant go more than one or two fights without being killed by a random, training grounds is a joke for the new player base, you have ppl high level like me vs very very low level players. How is that even fair???? Team objective with a party is yet another joke, you cant even play on the same team for more than a few matches. It'll put yall against each other.  Not fun.... The lag is a whole other issue as well. Coming from someone who runs 1gig upload and 1 gig download and still gets way laggy is a F'ing joke. Dev's basically left and noone knows when an actual update will be out. Given there history with prior updates i have no hope that this next one will be any good. The last few have been dumb, and more buggy than ever with no hot fix's to help. I loved this game and was my go to for awhile, but good things always have to die, and the dev's definitely killed this game. TBH they should sell it off to another team and hope they can fix what ShitBanner has ruined. The only thing postive about Chiv is that the cosmetics are dope, seems like they put more time into the cosmetics than the actual game itself. Sad sad ending to a once beautiful game.

I'm posting this here for two reasons: 

1: This game is incredibly fun. It's a fantastic mix of good combat, great music, hilarious wit and incredible graphics. For anyone reading this and trying to decide if they want to play the game, it has a similar premise to that of Battlefield (when it was good) mixed with medieval combat. There's a pretty substantial learning curve, but nothing that should keep players from playing the game. When you understand the basics, it quickly becomes addictive, and incredibly fun. I personally am unsure how sweaty the community is, but from just playing the game, it's not very competitive at all. Even when I lose a match, I realize that, unlike other multiplayer games like CoD or Apex, or even For Honor, I'm not angry at the loss. I just join another match, and enjoy the game for what it is; a good game. Plus I'm a medieval nerd, so I love it.

2: For anyone looking to purchase the game, I wouldn't take this warning completely to heart, as it seems to effect only a very small number of people on PC. I'm not sure how, but my game crashes constantly now, at completely random times. Sometimes when i boot up the game into the main menu, other times when I play through a match and it tries to load another. I've tried everything, from graphics settings, to validating the game files, to uninstalling and reinstalling, nothing seems to work. It seems to be an issue with the game, and has only become a problem recently, as i was able to play this game without fail on my laptop a few months ago. The only reason I'm putting this in my review is because I don't know where else to go, and i feel like it needs more publication, as this issue has effected enough people to be annoying. I love this game, and want to play it more, but can't because of this bug. Hopefully it gets fixed soon.

Outside of this new issue, the game is amazing, and if you want a fresh multiplayer game that doesn't suck, and isn't just another cash grab like Call of Duty, give it a shot!

At first glance, the computer game "Chivalry" may seem like mere entertainment designed to kill time. However, a closer look reveals that this game has much more potential in terms of education and socialization, both within the family and society at large.

Firstly, "Chivalry" offers an interesting context for exploring medieval history and culture. It provides an excellent opportunity for families to spend time together discussing historical events, social norms, and even the ethics of warfare. This can serve as a starting point for deeper exploration of history and culture within the family.

The second aspect is the development of team skills and strategic thinking. The game requires players to coordinate, plan, and make quick decisions. These skills are useful not just in gameplay but also in real life—within family relationships, education, and career.

Socialization is also worth mentioning. The game brings together people of different ages and interests, providing a platform for communication and the formation of social ties. This is particularly relevant for adolescents who are in the process of forming their social identity.

Lastly, "Chivalry" can serve as a tool for discussing broader social and ethical issues such as honor, justice, and responsibility. This can be beneficial not just for family upbringing, but also for the education of society as a whole.

The core gameplay of this game is solid, but there are several issues that detract from the overall experience. One major concern I have is the revised historical setting. While character customization and representation are important, making a game based on a historical era like medieval Europe, which was predominantly white, can feel out of place. It's essential to strike a balance between inclusivity and historical accuracy. If the game took a more fantasy-based approach, it might be more excusable to introduce diverse characters.

Another issue is the heavy-handed approach to censorship. While maintaining a clean gaming environment is understandable, outright muting players for trash-talking can be problematic. Trash talk and competitiveness have been part of gaming culture, and muting should ideally be a personal choice.

It's crucial to consider that the core issue might be the tolerance level within the gaming community. It's possible that players have become too agreeable and should establish clear boundaries for what is acceptable behavior in the game. Striking a balance between maintaining a respectful gaming environment and allowing for healthy competition and interaction is essential for a positive gaming experience.

Good fun.  

One game you'll de-limb people with a giant greatsword, pick up their arm, toss it at their friend to stun them and then cleave their head off.

The next game you might suck butts and constantly get plowed through the eye by archers wielding great bows, or pinned to a cliff-face by a ballista bolt.  

There's a good amount of variation, the learning curve to start is moderate, but you can play and have fun after an hour or so of practice.

The learning curve to git gud is ridiculous.  I don't think I'll ever get there with my ADHD brain, there are just too many different things that factor into your movesets.  I love it.  Couldn't recommend more highly for those who want a really awesome, immersive but still fun siege multiplayer.

If you have 30-40 ping you can't have a good experience with this game
You can't play objective based games without having 8 second input delay
You will lag backwards when you attack causing you to miss
You will fall into a pit every now and then due to input delay or lag putting you in there
Attacks will phase through people especially heavy attacks unless you're right next to them
Enemies attacks will go through first despite pressing them at the same time with the same weapon
If you duel someone with single digit ping you will lose, you never have initiative, you can not combo if you do hit them, you cannot counter or riposte, you cannot dodge
You will get a good duel every now and then which is the only reason i have 40 hours
Blocks will sometimes decide they won't block despite the ui showing you blocked
In objective based games you will never have fun unless you hold w and m1 with a maul as its the only way to "fight" anyone

If you can stand having all that happen while not playing the main game mode then sure buy it.

(It is a server issue considering I can play any gamemode other than the objective ones without having major input delay, but as soon as i touch objective i have 8 second input delay, doesn't matter if it's 64 or 40 people (or even 10 in one match i had) the input delay was still horrid)

Chiv 2 is a game that leans towards the casual side of competitive fighting games but also offers tech and meta for players who take themselves seriously and want a Competitive experience. The game has a few pros and some serious cons however, but I won't deter anyone from making this purchase if they want to.

First the pros-

1. Tech and Mechanics are really nice and easy to get into, the game can be made into a rock paper scissors fest where reading your opponents is vital to how you play. Accels and Drags still exists but not in a silly broken form such as Mordhau or OG Chivalry.  The game is accessible to anyone who just wants to jump in and have a good time as there isn't too much going on after you learn the basics. Maybe soft-feints and drags get a little goofy but as stated nothing nearly as broke as Mordhau.

2. Customization and personal effects on characters is fairly fleshed out, here is where I will give Mordhau the point however as Mordhau offers much more in terms of Customization, but the ability to customize here is still very nice and adds to the personality of your character. You can change Armor, helmets, patterns, voices, scaring, facial hair, and face template. Again it's not as much as Mordhau has going for it but it is still a very nice addition to the game, most of everything can be purchased with credits earned in game but some items may be locked behind a paywall which is why I still think Mordhau takes the cake on this.

3. The absolute silly-goofy stuff you can do in this game is incredible, from Yeeting rocks at people to beating someone to death with a chicken, there is a lot of choices to approach how you want to end somebody rightly whether by pommel or pomegranate (Don't know if it's actually in the game, but you can throw food and fruit at people for damage). 

4. The rather chill community that doesn't take itself super seriously, now you have a few people on here who absolutely feel the necessity to defend their sweaty titles, but as far as I've seen people do NOT take themselves super serious and often or not lend helpful tips to newcomers.

Now for the Cons-

1. Chiv 2 STILL hasn't fixed the Request null issue prompting you to have to change your wifi or disconnect your wifi and reconnect in order to actually login to the game. It can be pretty inconvenient at times, especially if you planned on playing with friends or not.

2. Servers suffer lag and bad interpolation from time to time, it isn't constant nor consistent but there have been times where multiple players in a single server complain about bad lag. I understand if the budget for the game is incredibly tight and there isn't a whole lot of space in it for better servers but I do highly recommend trying to buy into some when given the chance.

3. Certain voices past the OG's feel incredibly lack luster, like the Berserker for Masons or the Scotsman for Agatha. They have their personality but past the quirks of the voicelines they feel incredibly soft compared to what I would normally expect from them.  Maybe this is just a nitpick but I definitely feel that the Mason Knight, Agatha Knight, and Jolly Chef are the only good options in a game that offers plenty.

Again, I like the game but some issues are pretty major or minor at times so It's up to you if you want to purchase this game or not.

Chivalry 2 Combat Review

Ok I have played about 160 hours of the game and the time has come to write a combat review. I am going to split this review into two categories of pros and cons to evaluate it.


Pros:

The weapon skins look good.

It's pretty fun at low levels.

Swing manip is simple and easy unlike other titles, not much complex camera movement is required meaning most noobs will be able to participate in duels.

Range can be used to your advantage on long weapons.

I can see casual players enjoying this.


Cons:

Animations are generally floaty , sometimes feints won't resemble anything, overhead will look like slash and vise versa.

The many parry lockouts and cooldowns make the game feel janky and unresponsive

Counter-feints negate reading therefore the combat devolves into gamble reading and correcting yourself when you input incorrectly. Counter feints also dumb down swing manip (You can early counter, counter into an alt and run into the swing if its a drag).

Kicks are mostly useless gambles against good players so there aren't many ways to break an opponents held parry besides swing manip (read above) or draining their stamina.

Polearm animations are miserable to read. Riposte overheads look like flourish or something.

Initiative is non-existant resulting in confusing fights where a lot of the time you will take a longsword or heavy mace hit, directly after hitting someone and combo'ing. This is especially true with one handers.

The first person view models often obscure most of your screen, which isn't ideal when the FOV cap is so low. The alternative, thirdperson isn't much better as your player's model will also cover your opponents weapon thus making reading his attacks more difficult.

Jabs sound like a good concept on paper, but they are poorly executed in Chivalry 2, they are a mechanic used to re-gain initiative after taking a hit or missing etc. However nothing is stopping your opponent from jabbing you directly after you jab them, making initiative a sort of juggle between you and your opponent.

Spin to win is more alive then ever in Chivalry 2. Due to heavy defence, players have had to find creative ways to get around their opponents parry. Spinning was mostly a flashy move in other titles or a way to hide your animation but it is very viable in Chivalry 2 which is a bit cursed.

The fights sound like I dropped every pot and pan in my kitchen down a flight of stairs.

The counter window is as large as the windup of your weapon or something along those lines. This means that you cannot counter at the last moment to most accelerated attacks or you will riposte.

The many attack types like specials and alts result in an unnecessarily complex combat system, unless you have a mouse with 10 different keybinds you will often find yourself dying because you could not find your alternate stab keybind fast enough. These different attacks dont add more depth to the system but rather more muscle memory.

FTP (Feint-to-parry) is unresponsive so you will not be able to FTP successfully sometimes.

Dodging on every class results in fights that dont look like fights. It is not uncommon to swing at your opponent from your maximum weapon range, have them teleport out of your swing and due to the parry lockout, take a hit.

Matrixing is done by crouching and moving backwards, the animation however is really poorly made, you also cannot control your torso angle by looking up or down.

You cant parry arrows.

During a 1vX you are at the mercy of active parry which has been proven to be glitchy and unresponsive. A lot of engagements boil down to dodging around X opponents, riposting and blocking the rest of attacks with active parry (if it works).

Networking is unironically dogshit.


Let me know what you think down in the comments 👇

Love this game and have now clocked 442 hrs into this game.

Is this game balanced? No, not at all. Some weapons are much better than others, some maps are designed in favor of attacking or defending forces, and there are no skill groups, so you'll play with total newbies and level 200+ pros who play nothing except this game at the same time.

Is this game skill-based? To some extent. There are a bunch of tricks you can learn to fight more effectively, and you also have to learn how to position yourself, how to move, and how to be aware of the situation around you so as not to die shortly after respawn. But overall, you can run around slashing everything that looks like an enemy and have a fair share of fun.

Is this game fair? Hell, no. 80% of your deaths will come from a stab in the back, crossbow headshot, or 1v3 gangbangs. KDA players will run for the kills and won't ever play the objective and then call everyone else noobs. Lots of players will switch to the winning team all the time, and nothing can be done about it. 

But is this game fun to play? Yes, it is. It's epic, it generates hilarious moments sometimes, it actually doesn't have a high entry threshold like [b]Mordhau[/b], and it's quite a unique experience overall. I mean, imagine [b]Battlefield[/b], but with swords, spears, and medieval sieges. Totally worth it on sale, especially if you have some friends to play with.

I recommend buying this game. Player numbers rough around 2,000 daily or so. NA East servers tend to be plentiful still, so game is still alive, but I don't know how well this game will fair in the long run player-wise. Still getting updated though, so I think it has a good kick left in it still for a good while. Fighting in big battles with your team is really fun and was the main draw to me and I find the game delivers on that well alongside other aspects.

I find the melee combat really fun and one of the best I've played alongside Mount & Blade Warband. The mechanics of riposting, countering, kicks, jabs, positioning, all mesh well together I find to make an interesting combat system I love to learn and play with. The feeling of becoming skilled at this game creates some intensely awesome experiences I could only find in this game. Graphically, the game is great, but the voice acting is where I truly fall in love with it. I don't get tired still of hearing the same screams and quotes because there is a large variety of them and all have a substantial amount to say with great personality. Being able to throw numerous types of objects is also great and is one of the funnier ways to get a kill. I will note however that the balance of maps is skewed towards attackers. This does make me feel annoyed at times to play defense because I know that certain objectives are impossible to hold and are made so that everyone reaches the map's final grand objective. The best way I found to get around this annoyance is to just enjoy the combat that comes and ignore the objectives slightly. I find that enjoying the combat with other players and having little moments on the side instead of stressing over the objectives makes this game much more pleasurable. And if your team somehow does win in those early objectives, great. 

Player balance-wise the game is the usual with multiplayer games where there will be the level 1000 players that will be a league above new players, but I find that the 32 players on each team allows one to play against players of high skill and low skill simultaneously. I didn't expect to enjoy this game as much as I did, but the game presents itself well and plays great as well giving me one of my favorite medieval combat games to date. Heavily recommend and would love to see this game get updated faster and see more new players coming in, and this is someone that only starting playing years after launch. Give it a try at the very least if you enjoy intense, dramatic, and satirized medieval combat game that makes those huge clashes reality, and makes you laugh along the way.

Basically, enjoy the chaos and have some fun. Don't treat it too seriously.

At first the game was great and a ton of fun to just swing around and not worry about it and kill people.  First, I want to emphasize that [b]I really badly WANT to love this game[/b], it has such fantastic potential.

However, the more I learned about the game and how to play, the more I realized that the [b]game balance is REALLY poorly designed on a fundamental level[/b].  This combined with a couple of other big issues have really ruined this game for me to the point that the more that I play, the less fun it gets.

The biggest issue by far is that since they have introduced console crossplay the [b]servers have been absolutely horrendous[/b], with attacks and blocks not registering properly and enemies killing you from well outside their range in every single match.  If it weren't for this, I would probably still put up with all the other stuff below as well, but with it all combined together, was the tipping point for me writing this review.

Outside of the servers, my primary issue with the gameplay itself is that there are [b]a couple of strategies that will win almost every single time[/b], and most of the 1000 hour sweatlords that ruin lobbies for everybody else tend to gravitate towards those setups.  Combine this with the fact that a [b]large portion of the high level community will switch to the attacking team every single game[/b], and you commonly get a bunch of high leveled players stacking the same team and all using cheese strats against low level beginners.  [b]This makes games play very predictably, and it makes the high level gameplay not fun in my opinion.[/b]  

Prime example of one of these poorly thought out game mechanics is the [b]jab key[/b], which allows anybody to [b]interrupt any attack almost instantly[/b] with a quick offhand punch.  Since it is faster than all of the weapon swings in the game, it is [b]100% risk free to use,[/b] so long as you use it properly.  It more or less renders heavy weapons useless, the only reason you never hear about it is that the only people who know about it and use it regularly are the high level players.  A "good" player making effective use of jab spamming with a light weapon is effectively unstoppable without dog-piling them 6v1 or killing them with ranged weapons, despite the fact that this style of fighting is actually really easy to pull off considering you basically just smash the R key whenever anybody tries to attack you.

Also as an honorable mention: [b]Archers are extremely annoying and all around just a poorly thought out gameplay mechanic[/b], almost as if they were added to pull in and generate revenue from a group of players who cant or wont play the melee combat, and there is [b]very little counterplay against them (Only 2 of the classes have shields, and you can't block arrows otherwise, only counter them if you have perfect timing)[/b].  It is insanely dissatisfying to win a tough 3v1 in melee just to get picked off by an archer that you can't even reach without sacrificing yourself to the enemy spawn wave.  [b]There are no servers without archers or ways to still play team games without them present.  The only way to escape archers is 1v1 duel servers.[/b]

There are several other badly designed aspects of the game but I really don't have the space to fit them all in this review, so I'll leave it with these 3, as those are the most frustrating in my opinion.

[b]OVERALL:[/b] I can't recommend it for players who want to get into it long term.  If you're only planning on screwing around with your buddies for 20 hours AND the game is on a sale, it's a great buy (do wait for a sale to get other new players, otherwise the high levels will eat you alive).  However, if you were ever planning on putting in effort to get good at the game, and the image in your head of that was of epic and tense melee combat, [b]DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.  You will not find any cool sword fights at high levels, only the latest game exploits, jab spamming, meta weapons, and other associated cheese strategies that are never any fun to play against.[/b]

Incredible game, could say its the best melee out there. The combat is fluid and the learning curve is manageable, it is satisfying to play and can be quite addicting if you get into dueling. 

However the game suffers from terrible developers and moderators. There are bugs that has been in the game for months that are still not fixed. Griefers plague duel servers but never get punished, a moderator team that's quick to censor any criticism but will take 5-7 business days to respond to a help ticket, just to tell you there is nothing they can do about it after providing all the information they ask for about griefers.

I, due to my love for the melee genre, had put up with everything, even with the battlepass they're introducing, until today. The straw that broke the camel back was an interaction in their official discord. I logged on to have some morning duels and relax, and I was banned from the duel server due to griefer abusing one of the worst votekick system there is, for simply not losing my duels. I opened a ticket to get it resolved, never got responded but as soon as I made a meme on my situation and posted it on their meme channel, it was removed. Keep in mind that being kicked of the server simply because you're winning is a common thing, it happens often and unless you have friends in the server that'll vote against kicking you, there is nothing you can do about it, and TB has known about the issues since steam launch and had not made any attempt to improve it. 

Play it if you will, but don't expect to be treated like human by the devs unless you're actively shilling for the game.

I have a lot of fun playing this. The cavalry was a great addition. Love the 64 player mode too. Lots of hack and slashing, getting double and triple teamed against you at the drop of a dime.

Bottom line: the game is very very fun despite some small issues.

Combat (main chunk of the game) is phenomenal, multiplayer is addictive and enjoyable, connection issues are non-existent if you have good internet which is surprising for a game of this scale.

I have two main issues which are quite minor and easily addressable.
1: Servers do not have a queue system. If you try and join a full server you'll be kicked back to the main menu. Even when a free slot appears, if you're too slow and another player beats you guess what? Back to the menu for you bozo. Creates unecessary clicking and frustration. Easily solved by adding a waiting queue to servers.... Even Hell Let Loose, a game of much bigger scale and originally a tiny development team implemented this ages ago...

2: Small number of maps. There is only a handful of maps playable at time of review. After 10-15 games doing the same objectives starts to get a little old, but thankfully the combat is so detailed and well designed that this is just a small annoyance and not a dealbreaker.

Pick this game up for whatever price you can justify it for and lose a couple hours to Good Old Fashioned Medieval Fun.

Chivalry 2 is actually quite an interesting and funny project, in this review I will write why. the game is made in the style of the Middle Ages, which gives a certain charm, addictive and gives you the opportunity to return to the old days. The game boasts a huge amount of content that is added almost very often, as well as very beautiful graphics of bushes, trees, buildings, armor, weapons and so on. in high resolution, so graphically you obviously won't be disappointed if you have a good enough computer, everything is done in full in the gameplay, there are many different modes from 1-on-1 duels to mixed fights, where 64 people are on the map, of course, it may seem that this is not enough, but with taking into account the size of the cards and the number of people who fit on this map, this is quite enough, also in the game everything is distributed by classes, there are only 4 of them - archer, infantryman, knight, vanguard, they all have different weapons and there are no classes that could have superiority over anyone, in this game everything depends on you, on your gameplay and of course skill, there is nowhere without it, the selection of players by levels, there is simply no such thing here. absolutely any player of the 1st, 100th, 500th levels, it turns out that you come to play, but you are constantly being killed by players who play from the very beginning, so you need a skill to somehow resist such players. The training in this game is well conducted, it shows the basic mechanics of the game, after which it will become a little easier to play, this is where my review will come to an end, I strongly advise you to purchase this game for fans of the Middle Ages. this remains the best project in its genre, this is my personal opinion. I hope this review helped you a little.
