To add more gasoline in the flames of the two games rivalry (Mordhau vs Chivalry 2), here are my thoughts you may find relatable, retarded, ignorant, based or whatever else and its all fine: 

I played Chivalry 1 a few times when it first released and I have few hundrends of hours on Mordhau, now I got a bit bored by it so I decided to give a chance to Chivalry 2 some days ago and I can say the combat system and customizations are an absolute downgrade from Chivalry 1 and mainly Mordhau:
1. The combat system is primitive and makes no sense in a meaning, as a HEMA practitioner, parry and feits of Mordhau are how in the result the combat irl works when you simplify it. Constant block in the result is almost nonexistent irl (to some degree it basically exists only around shields because they are wider than other weapons, and guess what, there is a constant block for shields in Mordhau, not for regular weapons). A lot of people argument that you can constantly hold the weapon in front of you irl, so why not in Mordhau, well, because irl you always block/parry in an active manner, because of various angles, so irl if you mess up the angle and so the timing, you virtually mess up the parry window and get hit and because of the various angles feints exist to make you mess up the angle/window, which is exactly how Mordhau simulates the result of this principle in a simplified way, AKA the parry system contains dealing with angles without actually having to deal with angles, because it would be a keyboard mess, I mean it might seem its just a short block, so it might seem it also makes no sense as the constant block, but as I said its about the result, its simplified in a right way, so when you interpret it right you realize Mordhau devs actually know how fencing combat should work, for the most parts atleast. Tho they actually tried to make a mechanic that somewhat gets you as close as possible to the manner of having to deal with atleast some angles and those are chambers, while chamgers are also a very smart way of how to balance feints (I mean dont get me wrong, balance is very important for a game to be competitively enjoyable, tho Mordhau makes it in immersively sensible way). Which gets me to what I also prefer on Mordhau is the direction of attacks determined by a slight mouse movement, I find so primitive to basically have only 3 angles of swing determined by fucking buttons/keys, it takes away the joy of feeling like you actually control the weapon, it makes you less happy when you successfully decapitate someone, because you didnt achive this angle. I understand Chivalry 2 devs tried to make the combat system more simple so more accessible, but Mordhau combat system is much more satisfying when you learn it, because you achieved something and still achieving it from there on every single time you kill someone, while it also creates very loyal playerbase that doesnt seem to want to die. Chivalry 2 aims on quantity over quality in its playerbase, but did it really work, I mean Google player count of both games and make your own opinion on this.

2. The customization of characters is very restrictive, while the presets of gear are laughable mess, from goofy shaped kettle helmets, to brigandine with lamellar pauldrons, to weirdly chunky swords, to Mason's Men at Arms forced around round shields (which atleast would make more sense for Agatha as they are said in the lore to be a bit more wild and primitivistic, some of them being stylized around early to mid medieval gear). Also most of the preset gear looks like an armor put together by poor looters, each piece of the gear feels like it holds no identy together and its there just so there would be atleast something, like its with lazy intentions, its so random. I mean in Mordhau you see few people walking around naked with pans as a weapon, which is the direct result of almost unrestricted customizations, but a huge majority of people are actually making gears that both look good and make sense (not neccessary in a realistic way, but in an immersive way, in individually functional way with stylization), which to me is pretty ironic as Chivalry, through its lore, presents itself a bit more serious around roleplaying, while Mordhau is the mess... right? Well, now it feels mostly opposite. I tried to give it many chances but I felt little satisfaction or fun playing it.

One of the only things Chivalry 2 does very good to me is the faction lore system, the sense of purpose of all the battles, the joy of having a favorite side and being a bit proud when it wins (and thats something I miss a lot in Mordhau and hope for it if we ever get Mordhau 2, as Mordhau now tends to be more nihilistic), its so good also because both sides are well thought through to be very relatable: one side wants people of iron, competent, skilled and inteligent society by any means necessary, a side that was frustrated being ruled by weaklings that almost doomed them, so they fight for taking the lead in their own superior vision, they fight for the greater good, while the other side fights for a wilder sense of freedom, honor, faith and solidarity (tho both forcing their ideology upon all others). Also map/objective design is very good in Chivalry 2 (thats something Mordhau could also improve on). And as a final thing for fellow archers, Chivalry 2 is a bit better for it, mainly because of the zoom and defensively functional layout of the maps, but everything else is goofy in a sad way, so much so Im disappointed of the very disappointment, I mean I was really excited about trying it even tho I knew there are some certain differences between Mordhau and Chivalry 2, but I wasnt ready for this. Anyway still I will continue to play it for some time, because I still want to give it a chance and I want to see what atleast 100 hours will do to me.

The game is quite good actually, if you're looking to get onto the Melee genre type of games, this is a good one, classical "easy to learn - hard to master" type of stuff.

Still, there are a LOT of bugs, maps or certain areas are badly optimized, community can be quite toxic in general. 
The dev team seems to not pay much attention to feedback, (mostly related to bugs that are literally happening for years now), there is a lack of content, believe it or not.

Furthermore, you do get the typical updated behind a DLC or "Battle passes" or however you wanna call them, and it's basically skins or rather re-colored versions or skins.

The thing that usually annoys people the most is the poorly made "Attack VS Defense" trope, good on theory, badly made, I'll explain further:

So the team attacking usually has the advantage, the times required for them to "Win the round" and move onto the next objective is more often than not, really unfair, and players on the Defense team gain significantly less points, and usually higher leveled people notice this and change onto the Attacking team right when the match starts, so it's automatically unfair right off the bat.

The game is quite good, as I initially stated, but there are a lot of little nuances that keep it from being great.

I'll keep on playing this game even after all the backlash I just said, probably sounded like I'm negatively ranting against Chivalry 2, but again, I do recommend the game!

The reason I'm giving this game a negative review is because in the last three or four months I have been removed from games by hackers with no vote kick prompt multiple times now. The only time this occurs is when I have a high KD ratio or climb to the top of the score list. I've also had several instances where someone throttles my ping to over 1000 until i have to find a new lobby...It really is a fun game but I'm not going to play something where I'm constantly harassed by scumbag hackers. I'd rather be penetrated by archers. Be weary, this games security is definitely questionable...
Edit: It's been quite a few months and the community as a whole seems much less toxic. I have not had any issues with doxing or noticeable cheating since I started playing again. Excluding the odd 180 head snap archers. There are still connectivity hitches and frame drops here and there that shouldn't be, but I'm happy to be playing again without all the toxicity.
Highly recommend it, though I hope in the future they add voice chat to the game.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Broken hitboxes, missing hitboxes, garbage hitreg, garbage servers, even more hitboxes making no sense. What is there to say other than the devs cover up their lack of fixing bugs that have existed since beta with updates and ignoring the issue. First issue, shit not making any sense. The little ass jab that interrupts FULL attacks mind you, is not outshined by a fully charged fist strike or even the exact same jab attack, even if stronger while fist is equipped.  It just doesnt make any sense why that is the way it is. On top of that, theres the garbage stab hitboxes, stab spamming is a complete strat based on the stamina it takes, range issues/range buff, and just complete disregaurd for physics. You can "drag stab", even though that makes literally no sense, you can also barely, and i mean barely if at all touch someone with any part of a giant box at the front of the weapon and they will take full damage, even from the sides sometimes. The devs dont listen, fun game until you get past the original joy and realize the game becomes a cesspool of bad servers and latency resulting in a very displeasing time. Its fun when it works, rarely, and when it doesnt you certainly have a mood change as a result. It’s a medieval casual multiplayer game, but it’s really addicting and well polished. They don’t have much competition in this genre (maybe only [i]Mordhau[/i] and [i]Mount & Blade[/i]). The 64 players matches are really fun and brutal, involving the completion of multiple objectives within the time frame (similarly to [i]Battlefield[/i]). Multiple classes are available and they change your playstyle, but I must admit that there is no real skill in this game. There is some but only when you are facing one opponent, which is quite rare and eventually someone will run to assist you or kill you from behind. Most of the times you die after being attacked on all sides. Fortunately, the respawn is pretty fast, so you can try to take your revenge and die again. Playing as an archer is probably safer and gets you more kills from the distance. There might be cheaters, but it’s hard to understand who is really cheating unless you die with one hit and full health and even then I’m not sure cheaters are getting banned in this game. Community can be both toxic and fun, as usual. That said, this is a pretty unique and fun multiplayer experience. Despite being casual and sometimes unfair, I’m happy this is not another one of those esport games focused on online tournaments and streaming.

It's far from ready to be full released.

- Game-breaking bugs (King does not spawn, spawning into river, etc) (Update - these bugs seem to be fixed, but at rare times it still happens for other scenarios)
- Class balance is very off. Some classes are highly underwhelming compared to others
- Scoring system is dumb. Some of the highest damage dealers get the highest healing abilities, and the heals give a massive boost to score, whereas other classes get abilities that barely give score
- Very few maps
- Cavalry system is buggy. Collision and physics are weird
- Some charging abilities have buggy animation and collision detection

!!! The biggest one of all is that hackers are still common (flying in the air, speed attack) even in August 2023. This hack has been around for a long time. It is clear the devs don't care, so why should you bother giving them money?

This is a amazingly fun game with little to no bugs. Don't listen to the negative reviews about dumb lag, coding and hit boxes. 99% of the negative reviews come from drooling toads that have toasters as PC's.

Hilarious you still see the bug where commending someone for the first 5 seconds after death is rejected, and the GUI refreshes. However they're sampling user input it's clearly still only valid for the last 2 sec before you respawn. It's annoying pressing F to commend immediately just to have to press it again because it didn't actually record anything since it wasn't ready. The auto-kick algorithms for AFK timer and team damage surely are inspired or based off of in some large way on the monkey sort algorithm.

I bet $100 that the button(s) to report someone don't do anything. You're telling me I have to keep a program running in addition to Chivalry 2 that records the last 30 seconds of my playtime so that I can file a ticket with the mods on Discord in order to report someone? But the button that's in the game is enough evidence once you press it? If you require 30 sec of video I highly doubt you even store the lobby chat let alone use any functions to get the reported player's Steam ID and then compare it to what was said in the chat. 

The game is pretty fun in spite of the massive flocks of incels and racists who play the game. The algorithm for "You're leaving battle you're gonna die now if you don't return LOLS" is uber hyperactive. The AFK timer is equally overly active. The game really feels like it penalizes you if you need to step away to use the bathroom or do anything at all momentarily IRL. Players are also aggressive towards you if you AFK for even 1 second in the spawn. They will team attack you or votekick you if you happen to AFK briefly. Something is definitely in the Chiv 2 koolaid these people are drinking to make them unnecessarily angry at AFK players. There's already an auto-AFK kicker to kick people if they AFK too long, anyways. This isn't a super popular game that has an overpopulation issue, so votekicking and harrasing players that AFK momentarily is pretty funny since it's not like you're going to replace that AFK player with a more active one given the lack of popularity and player population. The auto-team damage kicker doesn't work well at all. I've seen people who had to be votekicked for TKing and they already had 200 - 300 + team damage but the auto-tk kicker did nothing. Meanwhile, the autobalance algorithm is basically nonexistent. I've seen it "autobalance" maybe once or twice, only 1 players. There are many games I've seen where one team clearly has more higher level players and their team also has a 100+ kill lead. If the autobalance were to work, it needs to balance the teams better so battles aren't always boring when one side is stomping the other. It's odd the game has been out for 3 years now and still doesn't have a workshop for players to create new maps. The new Bridgetown map is neat, but it's only offered "for a limited time", which is an odd way of gatekeeping new content from players considering we have no way to volunteer our help for free to make new maps and the devs prefer to release a new map once every other quarter, sometimes longer.

On the one hand this game is insanely addicting fun. Easy to pick up and feels rewarding to master, they have fixed a lot of the issues plaguing Chivalry 1.

On the other hand what passes for "skill" is often crouch exploits that give players free dashes in melee, rampant cheaters, and what appears to be unstoppable weapons no matter what you do. Today alone I watched as the "king" was taken down in one hit...twice! very very obvious cheating there. Anyone with a two handed ax just needs to keep swinging forever because there is literally no stopping them if you block, kick, punch, or hit them with your weapon, the same is true for swords it seems unless that is also another set of cheating. Many players appear to have arrows passing through them harmlessly. The thing about the cheaters is they are coming from Microsoft store, so EAC has no effect on them. The devs need to step up and set up in-game checks for things like weapon swing speed, damage, movement speed since there are hard-coded limitations to each weapon. Cheaters and exploiters are going to kill this game quickly, as they did Chivalry 1 and Mordhau. There is a clear market for games like this, so either step up devs before someone else does.

It is fun, easy to learn yet hard to master. I am still learning to fight and even though I am not the best, I can be competitive within 20 hours. Toxicity level of the people playing it tend to be low and game is balanced enough to be enjoyable. It is still important to find a good match. Sometimes uneven matches can become tedious as you are easily destroyed by competitive and coordinated groups. Still, this is not necessarily a problem. Good players tend to join the losing side to match the odds from time to time. Overall I am still enjoying it and the additional skins add extra fun to those who care about how they look when they are butchered. Planning to play it further, and expecting the new map anxiously. The maps lose their interesting sides as you continue to play them, but each game continue to be exciting due to competitive battles. If you enjoy such games, come and participate now :)

I want to start off by saying that Chivalry 2's core gameplay is absolutely amazing. With this said, the various and near constant technical and UI issues make it extremely hard to play this game for any meaningful amount of time. WIthin 3 back to back matches, there is typically an issue joining the 4th match. I have been outright disconnected from servers mid match, and the party system is a glitchy mess. The cross-play works well enough, but the versions of the game that are on PC do not function the same at all. The windows store version lacks many settings and the functionality that the Steam version has, which has become an issue at times when playing with friends who are, not on Xbox, but on PC. 

If you get this game on sale, it is very worth your money. That said, I cannot promote paying full price for a product that only works correctly 50% of the time.

After 350+ hours, I can honestly say, it's not worth it, unless you quit it at the right time.

The more you play the game, the more you realize how simply bad the servers, hit boxes, matchmaking, or simply the game overall is.

Might be fun and worth it if you just hop in the game, play just about when you start getting a little good at the game (perhaps around 120 hours, depends really) and then quit it and never play it again, because if you get too good at the game, you'll start to realize what drags you down and what ruins your gameplay, ignorance is bliss after all.

I'm a mild-mannered lady who mostly plays turn-based strategy. This game makes me a frothing madwoman who literally screams along with my character.

10/10, will unleash primal bloodlust again.

Are you tired of games with good controls?
Do you want to perform each and every basic move with a different keybind?
Do you want to play the piano?
Then look no further, Chivalry 2 is for you.

The control scheme of this game reminds me of old FPS games, where you would use the keyboard to look left, right, up, and down, instead of the mouse.

There are 9 keybinds just for attacking. I'm talking about slashing and stabbing, the core basic action of the game. Excluding the kick and throw.

They could have assigned 4 of those 9 attacks to the left click easily like how every other game does it. There are MMORPGs with less keybinds.

I can do every attack in Mount&Blade with left click, cancel/block attacks with right click. That's it. If I wanna stab, slash from left/right/up, that is my left click. I just move my mouse to the direction that I want to slash/stab from, I left click and it is done. But in this game every one of those attacks are a different keybind.

To cancel your attacks, you need a different keybind than your block aswell. If you use your block(right click) to cancel it you just block the air. If you press and release it real quick you can cancel it once or twice but eventually you are going perform the block animation. So again dedicated keybind it is.

You also need a dedicated keybind for "running attack". Because attacking while running is simply isn't enough, you need to press the magical key.

Mount&Blade, Mordhau, War of the Roses, Gloria Victis did it better than this game.

Once upon a time, in the midst of a medieval battle, I found myself armed with a wooden spoon and a pot lid, desperately trying to fit in with the brave knights around me.

As arrows flew overhead and swords clashed, I charged forward, banging the pot lid against my head in an attempt to intimidate the enemy. Little did I know, I ended up intimidating my own comrades instead.

In the chaos of battle, I mistook a cow for a fearsome warhorse and tried to mount it, much to the amusement of both sides. The cow simply mooed in protest, leaving me hanging on for dear life.

Eventually, the battle ended, and we emerged victorious. Covered in mud and shame, I couldn't help but laugh at the absurdity of it all.

Turns out, even in the realm of knights and honor, a wooden spoon and a pot lid can bring a touch of comedic relief to the battlefield.

I would recommend this game to anyone who wants a NOT PAY-TO-WIN, fun and very arcady multiplayer medieval combat game that has a lot of chaos. It's not too hard making it approachable to a beginner. The game has 4 main classes to choose from including archer, vanguard, footman, and knight. Each of the main classes contains a play style that allows you to play in many different ways. Each main class is comprised of 3 roles that you choose from in total allowing you to choose from 12 roles. It does have CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION for each class that you can manage with coins you earn by playing the game. It has multiple different modes and special limited-time modes once in a while. The game looks really well made with detailed maps and amazing graphics. Because it is a medieval combat game there is a lot of blood, gore, and dismemberment but there are options to turn them completely off. It has a little bit of comedy as your character might say comedic lines at times that can reference things. It does have micro-transactions like battle passes, bundles, and in-game currencies but they aren't shoved in your face and down your throat and you don't need them to progress through the game. The progression system is fairly balanced allowing you to gain rewards at a balanced rate. Overall I would definitely recommend this game

Ohhhhh

honestly this game is such a huge waste of money. i would go as far as to claim it's no better than a mobile game. the graphics are pretty nice, sure, but anything other than that is fools gold. At the very beginning of the game after the tutorial, you are asked which side you want to fight for, and this choice is utterly meaningless. I chose masons and yet, when I got into my first game, right off the bat i'm playing for agatha. I had to choose to switch teams, which is honestly a ridiculous feature in almost any game. It's a terrible gag and it demonstrates zero capability to properly keep games even. There is also a team autobalance system, which honestly just seems to not even work the second players might leave. i played an entire game with the player ratio being 9 to 11. Must be a really great autobalance system if it thinks 2 isn't a divisible number. The combat is atrocious rather you play archer or the other 3 classes. During my time as various melee units, there is a constant snapping that makes it extraordinarily hard to swing your sword, which is actually a fundamental mechanic in the game that gets hammered into you in the god dahmed tutorial. It almost seems impossible to swing your sword like an actual person would. The stamina system too. My god, the stamina system is ridiculously terrible. I would much rather go get absolutely wrecked by a centurion in For Honor having the stamina drained the entire time than simply try to have a normal fight in Chivalry 2. I can run dry of stamina after swinging one attack and blocking two or three attacks, then i'm broken and absolutely anyone can just wildly strike at me. I understand you don't want people blocking forever, and it could easily get abused if it wasn't handled properly, but it is far too late. The blocking system is already absolute garbage seeing as any attack i may give after a block most definitely isn't going to hit unless i can somehow get far enough out of a players view, and every person i've ever had attack me while i'm blocking is literally just non stop spamming attacks at me and they NEVER run out of stamina. How absolutely mental do you have to be to make that be how blocking and attacking works in your game. There is no skill, there is no following functions or getting into rhythms because the game mechanics go back on themselves and simple ideas you would think you just work simply do not. This game genuinely makes me feel like playing smart means playing exactly by a formula that quickly crumbles when you are getting ganked or someone is just spamming. And the archer class, by god. I have literally just watched my arrows phase through both enemies and teammates alike. Granted, it's a relief when a teamates steps in the way of the arrow and it just goes through instead of inflicting team damage, but when it happens to enemies it just makes any skill feel absolutely worthless. why should i even bother trying to hit a target 10 feet from me when the arrow will literally phase through their helmet. I enjoy playing the archer class a lot, and yet sometimes it literally feels like i'm trying to hold the game logic by a leash as it behaves like a wild rabies infested mutt that has no clue it even exists sometimes. it's even worse that the archer class literally run at the same speed as the knights even. there is no getting away if someone sneaks you or if you simply turn around and run away. It legit takes so long to start running, that if a small group of knights start rushing me from about 40 feet away, by the time i turn around and start trying to move, they're already swinging for me. This game is absolutely ridiculous and should never be taken seriously as any form of art. This game to me is the equivalent of staring at a painting that is a single stroke of white paint on a white canvas. Those in charge of this game should seriously be ashamed of their capabilities.

Update: i actually forgot to mention the stuttering problems the game has. get's a little irritating after a while. I've also spent more time using both mouse and keyboard as well as my controller and it doesn't really change much. I've also noticed how bad hitboxes are in general, which explains why arrows literally just clip through people. honestlty after spending more time in this game it's felt more and more like a joke and it seems like the community itself is also one. to each their own i guess, but jesus christ is this game just bad. i finally uninstalled and hope to never even have a thought about this game again.

I really like this game, but I can't recommend it.  

Map balance is really bad on a handful of maps.  Objectives, spawns, and timers need to be adjusted.  There is no reason you should be punished for doing well by having time subtracted when you win a stage (See: Raid of Aberfell attacking).

Hit boxes are awful.  Some weapons hitboxes are significantly longer than their graphics (ex: Messer).  In addition, sometimes you will desync and attacks will phase through enemies.  Combine the desync with a low tick rate, and dragging as a technique, and sometimes you are just going to have an awful experience.

Finally - The devs are mediocre at best.  Patches come out claiming to fix things, but they are not fixed.  They also ignore very real issues (desync, hitboxes, etc.)  Weapons unlock that are not in the game (ex: Level 22 Archer and the Siege Crossbow).

I will continue to play it, but you probably should avoid it.
really good game reminds me of older games that were just for pure fun

So... I play mainly on Epic store (150h+), but I decided that my recent experience with the devs of this game warranted a quick buy/review/refund, simply because I think people need to know what they are buying. 

When this game released on Epic, it was one of the favorites in my friend group. It is an awesome combat game and its great with friends and when you just want to blow off some steam for 20 min. The graphics are great, progression system is a bit of a marathon, but overall, its fun! 

That was our opinion in 2021... Since then, very few bugs have been actually fixed, you still cant tell your team mates apart from the enemy due to cosmetics, the griefing system known as the vote kick system is abused so badly its maddening (if you're first on the kill board, people will try to have you kicked from the server- and it'll usually work), the bugs are getting bad and the balancing that should have happened long ago never came (a 5foot executioners sword swings faster than a dagger). The new maps are so unoptimized that you can barely fight, framerates are sh*t on high end rig and its so bad that they even had to put off the newest content due to it straight up failing to work AFTER LAUNCH. 
The microtransaction store seems to be what they focus on these days, rather than gameplay or anything important and the worst part is below...

Now, beyond those, you will run into this every few matches, and almost every duel you enter has someone fighting like this:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bn2v9xoSz-w
This type of cheating is becoming bad in the game and when you try and use the vote kick feature, despite EVERYONE in the match agreeing they need to go, the vote instantly fails. In order to report them, you have to go onto the community discord and here is what you need:
-video evidence
-ingame name
-Steam/Epic ID
I presented this dude off the video to them and provided everything they needed, and I got banned from the discord. I signed onto the discord from an alternate account and all of the threads that were there a few days before that were asking the devs to deal with cheating were deleted as well, and all the people that had been posting them were also gone from the discord.  SCUZZY AS F*CK GUYS! 

So apparently this is the new norm for this game and it has ruined it for my entire crew. 

So as a review of this game, I would say AVOID AT ALL COST as the devs sweep every problem under the rug and dont care about the game or players.

Update 01.07.23: Now it is even a biger pile of garbage than it was. Please, don't waste you lifetime on this, like i did. 100% regret.


Game exit: non-existing.
No normal Exit option. Its either Crush+Send report window or black screen, which blocks your desktop or even BlueScreenOfDeath sometimes. You need to exclusively crush the game process through task manager to exit it. It is the year 2023 outside.

Netcode: non-existing.
It doesn't exist in the game. New map magically gives you 150+ ping on a random occasion. If you have 1+ people with a high ping, the whole server starts lagging. In close combat  game starts throttling network packets as shit and gives you x2 ping. Lads insist to scale their server infrastructure, instead they are making new cosmetics and one shitty map, which players hate.

Matching player's and server location for proper ping: non-existing.
It's recently threw me 5 times in a row onto london-classic servers, on which i have 150 ping. I kept exiting and starting again. It kept threw in london. f*** this.

Balance among classes: non-existing.
The balance exists only between knights or vangs with 2-handed axes and swords. Archers and footmen classes stamina, damage(this one depends) and health are pathetic. Even for their heavy-armored allies, wildly-blindly swinging their 2-handed weapons. 

Balancing of player levels between teams: non-existing.
Recently played a map, where our team consisted by 90% of <lvl10 people, while  other one was mostly >lvl40.


Don't understand me wrong: the game is fun. But it is not a "decent game" fun. It is a "messy chaotic hell noncense mixed with rage" fun, like Fallout76 on start. Or Battlefield 2042, when it spawns tanks on your head.

I put off getting this game after the E3 reveal in 2019.  I was deterred by its Epic Game Store Exclusivity and the reveal gameplay being pre-rendered footage.

Only now in 2023 have I tried it out during a sale and, after one and a half hours, refunded.

The good:
1 - 2 populated Australian servers

The bad:
no 64 player servers...  only 40 max!
combat is totally pared back and feels more like Call of Duty: Medieval Warfare than Chivalry.
Graphics wise... it has a very Unreal Engine generic look to it... almost feels like a college project with how glossy things are.
Whilst it is bloody... it totally lacks any weight or immersion compared to the original.
In other words, a totally casualised and bastardized version of what Chivalry 1 was.

I wanted to give it a solid try before posting a review. This pains me on so many levels to say no at the moment. The fantastic gameplay, character interactions and fight mechanics are solid! I think each person will have their own tastes on this, but it is quite fun. However, its the ankle biters that make the overall experience a bad one.

First is the respawn mechanic. There rarely is a rhyme or reason to the timers and spawn positions. Nothing can be more frustrating to gamer and just sit in re-spawn timer hell while other teammates that died after you, spawn in a wave earlier then you. A few maps do not have the right atmosphere with those spawn points and timers;  leading to a incredibly  frustrating experience.

The second, is the objectives. Each objective has goals for a team, either push a column, burn a tent, hold a flag point and etc. Some maps have back to back objectives that do not contribute to the enjoyment of a battefield experience. One in particular, is the map where you spawn as peasants..... twice.... while the other team is fully geared and ready to go. In my viewpoint, players are human and will react as so. Forcing a player to be a peasant twice in a row against a heavily armed foe is not a fun one. SUre, you might get a zinger kill and feel good for that one kill. But overall experience on the map, is not for fun.  Contrast it with the other map where all the peasants from both teams duke it out before respawning in normal gear. NOW THATS FUN! It adheres to both sides on an even playing field.

Lastly, the topic of even playing fields. If you favor a map creation on just one side, it takes away some of the fun for the other team. While it's cool I can spawn in as a monk on last obj, how cool would it be if players on the opposing team could do the same but with their own niche as well. Then it makes the interactions a lot more fun.

All in all, I think the game has initial fun fare, but lacks sustain and longevity of both content and gamer engagement.

I got tired of COD, FPS type of games. Kinda like bubble gum after a while, just no flavor in it. I checked out Chivary 2 on a Free Weekend, First match, I got my arm chopped off. Chivalry 2 is essentially just Mordhau but more forgettable combat, but better invasion maps. Everything about this game is just so forgettable. Nothing stands out. If you want to play a medieval combat game, play Mordhau. Mordhau has it's abundance of problems, specifically with the developers essentially neglecting it, but you will get so much more out of it. Chivalry 2's skill ceiling is essentially 1 meter high. Mordhau's is hundreds. Mordhau has mod support, community maps, community servers, and far more stuff for your money. Chivalry 2 just doesn't have that. It's combat feels weightless and without strategy or purpose. I just can't get myself to like it.

I waited a long time for this game to release on Steam and now that it's here, I can't help but feel a tad bit disappointed and really wish I could just give a "neutral" review. I'll give my TL;DR of pros and cons

Pros:
*Fun maps
*Excellent class balance
*Sound design
*Objectives are fun 
*Being able to take on more than one opponent is satisfying thanks to new mechanics
*Models and textures are good
*1st and 3rd person are cool

Cons:
[strike]*Somehow difficult to play with friends due to their invite system. Let us just join through Steam. Your main menu friends thing sucks, fix it or get rid of it.[/strike]
*Wayyyyy too easy to block/counter. This leads to fights that can last a ridiculously long time if both players have half a brain cell or played the tutorial. 
[strike]*Time to complete objective is completely scuffed and offensive team is completely unbalanced.
*Bugs galore  [/strike]
*Weapon balance is all over the place 
*Lack of voice chat leads to many moments where gameplay is negatively affected due to lack of cooperation

Honestly, I try not to compare this game to Mordhau because they're two different games, but in many ways it's clearly better gameplay wise and I'd recommend you check that out first before you consider getting this if you're a veteran of medieval combat games. If you're new to this genre however, I'd watch some gameplay and give it a try if it seems interesting. This game has a lot of potential to be great, but Torn Banner has some work to do if they want to retain their growing playerbase. THIS IS NOT A BAD GAME, it just needs some polish.

[strike] My honest recommendation for the devs? At the very least, please reduce stamina of blocking and/or increase the punish for it. It'll make the gameplay more smooth, fun, and fair. Work on the friend list compatibility with Steam. Lastly, the gameplay should be your top priority of balancing because Epic Games players apparently didn't give you enough feedback.

Side note (doesn't affect my scoring): This is not available on Steam Deck/Proton... why? At this point, there's no reason to prevent Linux players to play the game they paid for. Valve gave you easy tools to use to fix this, so please do that. [/strike]

Edit: 
I'm editing this review quite a bit since some significant changes have been made. Also, they enabled Linux support which was a huge plus and a big win for Steam Deck players. My only major gripe now is the weapon balance and archers are absolutely horrible to play as. Genuinely one of the worst archer experiences in any game. Other than that, solid game 8/10

Accurate representation of Football Hooliganism in the 1990s Britain.

If you're expecting any sort of skilful sportsmanship, look elsewhere.
Of course, there are people who revel in the blood of the opposing FC, despite being outnumbered. 
Sending high frequencies and unwanted frequencies throughout their body. 
So that, the hail of blows from the crowd surrounding them seemingly phase through. 
Sounds an awful lot like the legend of Star Platinum to me!

Their next move? Well, as any true God would, they charge up their oversized anime sword and start up Dynasty Warriors on the PS Vita. 
Sending a viscera of ragdoll and limbs throughout the atmosphere creating ripples inside the time and space continuum of the surrounding netcode.

Sure, there are 1v1/3v3 playlists. 
However, that's also where the combat's flaws come to prominence.
I'd expect a working armour system for the next entry but what we have is desync as is.

By far the biggest production value in the genre and a spectacle.
At the same time, Battlefront with swords, doesn't get more casual than this.

To conclude, a moshpit filled with high society individuals, having highly intellectual discussions on various world carving matters. 
Including Yer Mum. She could certainly feed everyone. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

I really would like to recommend this game to new players, but I just can't. TB are fucking it up really bad right now, not listening to the problems the community is having, releasing major updates that somehow break the game further, major game-breaking bugs like intense stuttering and lag spikes, and even more issues that I don't have the energy to write out. If you want more information, Ziggylata (https://www.youtube.com/@Ziggylata) is a YouTuber/Twitch streamer who plays Chiv 2 a lot, and I believe he recently posted a video about the current state of the game. It is unacceptable how Torn Banner is handling this game currently. This game could be so much more, TB is hurting the game's potential with what they are (or aren't) doing. I do love this game, it is probably my favorite multiplayer PvP game right now, and these devs are making me so incredibly disappointed and sad. I can only hope that this game somehow gets better, but the pessimist in me is more realistic, I guess.

TL;DR
Basically this game is in a really bad spot right now, which means that I cannot, in good faith, recommend this game. Even if I do love it.

This game is better than Mordhau... that's about all you can say in its favour.  The fundamentals of movement and combat are pretty terrible.  Movement is janky, the geometry is oddly 'sticky', like a ten year old game made by some third rate developer.  Combat is just nonsensical, the physics are just 'lol'.

It has crossplay.  So I will keep playing it.

edit:  I'm not going to keep playing it.  This is a profoundly broken game, the basic mechanics just do not make any sense.  You can easily be killed by a stationary weapon - I once went 75 and 5 just by learning to stab and 'wiggle' my mouse, exploiting the 'release phase', which causes damage.  like, devs, just go outside.  pick up literally any object and move it through space.  pick up a stick and swing it.  doing this one time will give you all the information you need to fix your system.  it really, really is that simple.  stationary stick = zero damage.  moving stick = some amount of damage.  it causes me psychic damage to type those words, but I do it, for you.  

roughly 25% of players are using 'auto blocker' cheat software, this becomes sadly obvious once you get decent at the game.  once you realize it, it's easy to exploit with kicks but come on... once 1/4 of your player base is cheating, it's time to fold it.

devs, i'm talking to you again: you know you've failed, here. just stop. you don't have to make a game available.  you did a bad job here, you've released a thing that made the world a little bit worse - just try again.  just stop now.  rest.  maybe next time make something not terrible.  or maybe pick another career, like welding.  or carpentry.  something you can be proud of.  something not like this.

This game concept has so much potential but i can't bring myself to recommend anybody get it given the state of the game and how the devs have handled it. 
This is another game that takes the devs months to fix even the most well known, game breaking bugs, and that is IF they even fix them at all. There has been a problem with stutters in the game for a while. just a few months back a few people in this community found the source posted a temporary fix and sent there findings over to Torn Banner. Its been almost 3 months and they have done absolutely nothing, they even continue to release major updates which only further break the game. Cross platform was something that promised from the beginning but since release about a year or so ago has been barely functional if at all.
For me personally I really enjoyed this game, even just learning to play while dying over and over in the beginning but now that I know how to play all these stutters and other problems have just made the game so frustrating. If you want to go far you need to have at least below 40 ping or you just wont be able to fight. This game has decided I no longer live in NA west and now puts me on central or east servers which I'm lucky to get sub 100 ping in.
I have no idea what is going on over at torn banner but given their history and there neglect of this game so far I just can't see this game getting any better. The company seems like they will neglect the game because they can get away with ignoring us which is exactly how torn banner killed chivalry 1 back then. I will not recommend a game that the devs do not care about.

> be me
> arrive home after getting blasted by work
> prepare for nightly dose of escapism via pixel warfare
> Devs just dropped a patch for Chivalry 2
> PogChamp.jpeg
> "BUGS FIXED!" they say
> join 64 player melee, 'The Fall Of Lionspire'
> spawn in, prepare for glory
> block timing more out of sync than a bad lip dub
> dead within seconds
> respawn.exe
> block, fail, die
> rinse and repeat
> latency at 150, higher than Snoop on a Saturday
> ragequit.jpg, search for new server
> 'The Breach Of Baudwyn'
> check ping, now at 180, rising faster than Bitcoin '17
> nope.avi, search for new server
> 'The Slaughter Of Coxwell'
> ping finally at 12, the second coming of Christ
> spawn as peasant, last point defending, team being steamrolled harder than roadkill
> "YOU DIED"
> alright, let's try again and waiting for the next map
> 2 minute loading screen
> 'The Fighting Pit'
> ping shoots up to 190, EA levels of disaster
> disconnect, new server search
> 2 minute wait
> 'The Fall Of Lionspire' again, like a bad deja vu
> teams as empty as my bank account, ping normal
> decide to suffer, play anyway
> actually decent, server fills up, light at the end of the tunnel
> next map, 'The Raid On Aberfell'
> check ping, 200 now, rage quit 
> uninstall quicker than you can say "microtransactions"
> mfw they turned Chivalry 2 into Latency Simulator 2023
> a moment of silence for the great game that was

Absolutely wonderful. Chiv2 gives off a more gritty, down to Earth, and sinister atmosphere. However, it doesn't lack in the comical part of the original either. It's goofy and fun, but serious. If you've not played Chivalry MW? Then you don't need to read any farther. The game is amazing and you will have a good time no matter what. Nothing involving gameplay is locked behind a paywall. Only cosmetics! Just like it should be. 

If you are coming off Chiv1 after the actually recent complete death of the American playerbase? You'll transfer over fairly well. The only complaints you will have is customization and how all over the place it is. Chiv1's customization UI is extremely simple and IMO was superior. In Chiv2 you'll spend more time just navigating the UI for it but not to terribly bad. Also color choice isn't a thing anymore, as well as full choice of your insignia. You're color/insignia is depicted by "Heraldry" and they are set in stone color wise. There are a LOT of Heraldry options though, so it's not that bad. RIP days of making a full solid red/blue/white/black Knight. 

Combat is heavily updated but the same in many ways. You have a few other options in attacking now. Like heavier swings on ALL attacks, punching/kicking is now a thing alongside shoving still. Archers now have more attacks with bows. Like stabs with nocked arrows, punches, and kicks to create distance. 

Dodging with the MAA is now across the board. You no longer need to be a MAA to dodge. 

There is a jousting mode. I have not played it because I'm not interested. If I do play it I will update my review. 

There is a new faction, "Tenosia". This faction is Arabic in nature. Most of this factions customization is tied to gameplay and not monetization. I'm not a big fan of this faction honestly. I never really liked Arabic arms and armor. However, it is fairly accurate to history though and I can say I have no qualms with the addition of another faction in the universe. 

A lot more lore now. You can read the history of the world, and there are campaigns. They are NOT single player. More like progression with classes and feats to accomplish in game. 

Chiv1 players WILL be called cheaters and if you were good at the first game? Then your actual level is probably around 100 or so. I'm a level 12 and can take on level 100s more often than not in a fight. Third person is a bit closer than I'd like but it still is usable.
Hammer go brr. Game fun.

This game is amazing!  I have over 470 hours as I write this.  
You can chop heads off, grab the head, throw it at an enemy and if you're lucky, kill that enemy!  Then chop his head off his dead body, take his head and throw it!
You can chop off arms and legs.  You can throw any weapon you want.  They have cabbage, pumpkins, horsehoes, barrel, boxes, wheels, peasants, pigs, bread and chickens that you can throw at people!
I leveled my knight to 100.  My vanguard is at level 40.  Im working on my footman right now at level 35.  
I started using a mixture of weapons, but then used the Longsword until level 45.  Then I went to Maul and the War Axe.  After leveling them to 30, I went back to one handed weapons, like sword and shield, and found out they are much easier and faster to use.
Im at level 170 - 190 overall right now, i dont remember.  Close to hitting 200 though.  
At first the game is somewhat hard, but then you play the tutorial and figure the game out.  You can have good duels and survive.  You can take on many enemies at a time and kill them all and survive.  It's amazing the kills you can get in this game.  I have recorded a lot of videos because the kills were that good!  

As of the recent Raiding Party update, it does seem to lag a lot more when I first start a game.  I find a lot of high ping players in my server these days.  I'm usually at a 0 - 20 ping.  Maybe the next update things will get smoothed out even more.  Looking forward to that!

As someone who has purchased this game (Twice, might I add), and accrued over 500 hours total over the past two years between Epic and Steam, I wish I could recommend this game, but I honestly cannot fully do so in good faith. This game, much as it is beloved by its most dedicated community, is suffering a huge list of problems, and Torn Banner Studios is... interesting.

Firstly, I'm going limit mentions of this review's purpose to only Chivalry 2. Torn Banner themselves, and all previous titles before this in addition, will remain minimal at most. With that out of the way...

Chivalry 2, in its broadest strokes, is at its most, absolute fun when it works. Combat is robust yet simplistic, offering a lower barrier of entry than most other first/third person slashers to date, especially its predecessor and Mordhau as two big examples of comparison, but there's still a lot of room to work with in terms of manipulation and expression of skill. It is also only helped by the game's audio design being focused on the raw, savage cacophony of swords clashing against others, maces and hammers blunting against each other, and especially when such weapons collide with the person behind the opposing force. This is the part I have nothing but praise for, and commend the efforts of Torn Banner for characterising this so well.

HOWEVER... This is where my praise falls apart. Where the base foundation is absolutely solid, the supports, comparatively are not. There is, and have been, a myriad of issues that have plagued this game since even its very release, especially as of Patch 2.8: Raiding Party--and this is only further compounded by the current Patch not fixing *any* of the bugs introduced as of 2.81, most notably the Invalid Join Data mismatch and the horrendous stuttering issue that plagues a huge number of the community at large, and especially renders Console almost unplayable in many respects. Furthermore, Crossplay parties are still nonfunctional (Despite TB themselves claiming otherwise), and the stuttering problem is caused by how the game performs networking checks, which have been proven to be easily solvable by two people, one being Ziggylata (a notable community figure for Chivalry 2 as a whole), and the other a modder who performed a more elaborate fix that even reduces some of the drawbacks to Ziggylata's method. Finally, there is also the biggest issue that still exists, the netcode. It is not a comprehensible netcode, and due to the way it functions, there WILL be times you see weapons passing through players and dealing zero damage, among other things that can happen simply because... they can. And it has been this way since day one, and it is astounding that this has NEVER been touched upon.

Along with many, many other issues that add up, Chivalry 2 is a game that, at its core, is amazing... However it is also mired with a fundamentally broken set of supports that simply cannot hold the metaphorical house up. Why is this?

A part of this is due to development mismanagement, most likely, but it could be benign yet very harmful mistakes that weren't caught. Or it could be full incompetence. It could be anything, but historically, Chivalry: Medieval Warfare had no such large, glaring problems (aside from balance, far as I can remember), and it was much more stable in performance. Whatever the reason for all of these issues, it is inexcusable that such problems have existed for over a year, if not the entirety of this game's existence since commercial release, and that some of these fixes have not even solved these problems, and then created *MORE* problems unrelated to the original issue.

This game needs help, and while I want to dearly love this game, I cannot in good conscience recommend this readily. I would genuinely wait until the game recovers into a much more stable--and sustainable--state if you have any inclination to give this game a try.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
If you like goofy melee combat and don't mind the occasional map glitches, give it a try!

I played the Chivlary: Medieval Warfare for so so many hours. This "sequel" is like if you took Chiv 1, balanced a whooole bunch of stuff, removed all of the cheese-able stuff, added better animations, more customization, more dynamiclevel objectives, more useable objects on every map, more factions, etc, etc.

If you are a fan of the first Chivalry, you WILL love this one too. (There are a few key changes that take a bit to adjust to- Play the Tutorial!)

Bottom Line: I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the first Chivalry game, and I would highly recommend it to everyone to try. This is still the best series for a First Person Melee game, bar none.

Game is fun to play at times, but that's where it ends. The game is very unbalanced, from the maps to the weapons. Everyone uses a two-handed axe (Dane or Executioners) or the Highlander Greatsword because they are utterly broken. (Highland Sword got nerfed thankfully, Dane Axe remains completely broken).

Maps are unbalanced in the sense that the attackers get very high advantages while the defenders get shafted. Be it extremely generous time windows for the attackers, or an almost impossible way to defend objectives when the enemy attacker literally has a dozen ways or so to get to said objective - along with the defenders' spawn point literally being HUNDREDS OF METERS away from what you're supposed to defend. 

Everyone gets a dodge, which in Chivalry 1 was unique to the Man-at-Arms. Oilpots in this game are broken, they are spammed everywhere and even standing inside it for 0.5 seconds means you'll lose half of your entire health. Block-holding ruins the combat of game, paired with absolutely abysmal hitboxes, server lag and de-syncs. I have lost count how many times my sword or two-handed hammer literally went through an entire enemy's torso and did absolutely nothing. 

This game will suffer just like Mordhau and Chivalry 1 did, at least the combat in Mordhau was consistent. In this game it is not. Sometimes my kick interrupts and staggers a blocking enemy, or an enemy with a shield. Sometimes it doesn't. With the latest patch, the block hitbox has even increased further, which is absurd. You could already hold block and the only thing you need to time correctly are counters, now with how laggy, stuttery and de-syncy the game is - it almost feels like sometimes enemies have a 360 degree block window. Especially notorious on shield users.

For anyone who enjoys semi-realistic melee combat in a Medievalish setting, it arguably sets the bar and I can enthusiastically recommend the game, with some caveats. For comparison, I also put around 200 hours into Chivalry 1 (which was the reason I even got steam), and 130 hours into Mordhau, the main competitor, and ~50 I would estimate of For Honor.
The classes are mostly balanced and feel different, can be tailored and customized decently well for the main 2 factions, and feel unique. The maps and objectives are often cinematic and large, and in first person, quite immersive. If you played Mordhau or Chivalry 1, I would add that they have changed the gameplay, mostly for the better; you can hold block, throw any weapon, and have an interrupt and special attack for each weapon, as well as the community being less toxic than Mordhau. There is still a mild, continued story told between the maps, for those who care about lore, with the recognizable factions and characters (and yes, there are named, playable characters too for top scorers) that give the game character.
However, there are some issues. Updates often come slow and are small in terms of new inclusions. More of the new cosmetics are locked behind battle passes, whereas before most were purchasable with earned ingame currency; unlike other games, the battle passes so far don't expire and you can do any you miss as of writing, but you still must pay for them. The third and new faction, Tenosia, has limited, expensive (for ingame currency), and honestly bad cosmetics outside of the newest battlepass. If you are used to the old Chiv 1/Mordhau fighting style and customization, then that can't be helped. However, those aside, the game is a more than worthy successor to Chivalry 1, and a better successor than Mordhau, in my eyes.

This game is an awful lot of fun and incredibly satisfying. Honestly, nothing beats the combat which is simple enough to be accessible while having just enough depth to be really satisfying when you outplay your opponent. 

There's a lot to be said about interacting with other players. It's kind like TF2 in a way, where the limited voice lines can make for some very funny conversations. Part of me is glad there's no team voice chat but I kinda want to see what kind of chaos that could bring. 

Even the game pass is nowhere near as predatory as some games. They give you unlimited time and you earn nearly all your money back over time. 

However, it is still a tough sell for its price. It's straight up only multiplayer and honestly the game could use a few new maps. What it has are great for the most part, with only some minor balance issues for one side - I'm looking at the latest map in particular when the attacking team has absolutely no time to complete their objectives. It doesn't help when it can feel that you repeat the same maps over and over again but the game play still holds up even then. 

One thing I would say is to please let parties stay on the same team. As much as styling over my older brother is fun, he needs all the help he can get! It ruins the night if we're switching teams half the time. 

Also, the fact that some weapons can hit you when you're behind the enemy gets annoying but I'm just nitpicking now. 
Definitely get this game while it's on sale but if you have the cash, it's worth the price.

The absurdity and interactivity built into Chivalry 2 gives it a more lighthearted tone when compared to Mordhau. The overall combat in Chivalry 2 seems to be more inline with an arcade game when compared Mordhau's combat, and it's a nice break here not dealing with the toxicity produced by Mordhau's community.

If you prefer a large-scale sword game focused around sieges, Chivalry 2 takes the cake in that aspect. Though if you prefer more smaller modes such as duels or 3v3, Mordhau triumphs there.

The combat itself is fun and engaging,  the graphics are very nice.  There is a high degree of freedom in your combat style where you can mix things up to create your own style.  Blocks, kicks, counters, throws and a multitude of striking angles, accelerations etc makes it a very diverse combat system where you will bound to find something you like.  The game is however hindered by the following problems.

1) Matchmaking
From my experience with the game, very little thought seem to went into making both teams balanced during matchmaking.  Teams will have players in single digit levels all bunched up in a single team facing off against 5-10 stack level 300-900 players.  Teams also do not fill up evenly when new players join the game.  So you will have a team of 5 players vs 7 players but the new player will still go to the 7 player team.

2) Attacker advantage 
Significant advantage in favor of attackers in most maps as most attack objectives can be accomplished with bum rushes or involves breaking or taking certain resources that does not flip the progress bar the other way once attack side gets progress.  Defense side requires extensive knowledge of choke points as well as teamwork.  Which isn't to say it cannot be done but with how much of a mess the matchmaking is, attack side requires so much less teamwork than defense.  Attackers are also given way too generous amount of time to complete objectives, and the game actively hampers defensive side with very far spawns and the deserting system, which we will get to later.

3) Team swapping
The game allows swapping of teams throughout the game.  Which causes most players to pile onto attack side or whichever side is more favorable on the specific map.  Making the teams further imbalanced.  Which  makes defense side even harder to play when people straight out swaps off the team or just leaves.

4) Auto-balancing
The game's answer to the problematic matchmaking comes in the form of their "Balancing" mechanic that only seems to trigger very late into the match in which it force swaps the best players in the winning team.  The player that contributed the most in their team throughout the whole game into the losing team.  This is very insulting and disrespects the hard work the player put into the match.  So many games where you will think you finally have a good match then players fro other team will drop out of the game and you will suddenly get swapped into the losing team in the last 1-2 minutes just to take a defeat.  Which is extremely frustrating.

5) Deserter system
When objectives changes, you are given 20 seconds to move to the next objective zone or you will commit suicide once timer runs out.  And so many of these zones are sooo far apart especially when you are in the middle of an epic duel.  Some will have you run from the field all the way back up the walls while having 2-3 guys chasing you around.  This forces you to die and respawns if you catch the zone change mid fight.  The deserter zone also kills any ambush/backline assassination play styles.  While archers sits at the other side of the map sniping you with a warbow, you can't approach them without risking zone out if you run melee.

Once again, the game is not a bad game.  Combat is solid, graphics are nice, and the 32vs32 skrimishes are epic, but the game is held back by some very fixable problems.  A dive into improving the matching making and a tweak here or there on objective timers/zones and I believe it will take off.  But until these problems are addressed, at the current state of the game, I cannot wholeheartedly recommend the game to my friends.

Compared to Mordhau, there are some major differences: Chief among them is rascism/un-inclusive community issues; Mordhau has aged out of these in many regards, and both the devs and the player base have changed in the last several years from one of the worst offenders in video games to a place that is acceptive of various people regardless of race gender etc. Chivalry, on the other hand, is still a very toxic environment, especially in duel servers. It's not just the kind of character you can play, it's the way people act and what they say. To me this the most important aspect of an online game, and I think it should be the most important aspect to you as well.

Gameplay-wise, though, the two are very similar. Chivalry is more forgiving to players new to the genre, while Mordhau is very unforgiving. The horse mechanic in Chivalry is, I'm sorry to say, garbage and Mordhau's horses are much better handling and much more fun. The graphics of Chivalry look more up to date, but Mordhau has much larger battlefields with less restrictions on where you can go or when. Chivalry feels somewhat more cinematic but leaves something to be desired.

Overall, I would recommend either game but they are very similar. The main non-community difference is that Chivalry 2 is very lacking in armour and costume options, which is the main reason I like games like this. Mordhau definately trumps Chivalry in the customization area.

If you played Chivalry: Medieval Warfare and loved that game (despite its many bugs, most of which only added to the game), then you have to purge all the mechanics that made C:MW great and relearn the mechanics for this game. It's a good game in its own right and has a large burden to bear by trying to carry on the legacy of its predecessor. Some of this it accomplishes with aplomb and in other regards it falls flat on its face.

Pros:
+ True cross platform play (after two years)
+ Hack and slash fun (no limb is safe from being severed)
+ Many throwables, including your own weapons and even severed limbs (and good ol' dung)
+ Pick up heads and throw them
+ Creative and great looking maps
+ Visual assets are fantastically drawn
+ Many great skins to look at
+ Despite having no private servers after two full years since its official release, there are pockets of good communities on Discord to find and join up
+ Weapons feel weightier and more impactful than from Chivalry: Medieval Warfare
+ Soundtrack is pretty good
+ Buck-Ock

Cons:
+ Bugs bugs bugs (the developers only focus on visual assets and adding new skins, they do not put much, if any, focus on fixing core game play issues so expect to see some bugs, sometimes they break the game)
+ Team balance is still very much an issue after two years. Expect to play entire matches with one team having four extra players and no one is switched by the game
+ Horse controls are very counter intuitive (you have to aim the camera in order to turn your horse)
+ Spawns for Team Objective maps could easily be reworked to make them more balanced (usually the game will spawn characters on one side of the map when there's two objectives, forcing the player to run all the way across the map when it could just spawn them center of the map)
+ Some objectives in Team Objective matches are not balanced well (looking at you Stronghold)
+ The developers are slow to address game breaking bugs and will usually do so when releasing new visual content such as skins or a new map


All in all, the game is great fun, but I would wait until there is a sale to purchase since the replay ability diminishes quickly outside of joining a community on Discord or having friends to play with (no private servers to hang out in and play with general community yet).

First, I'll start by saying that if you're as committed as I am/was, remembering all the fun from the first Chiv, I would ignore this review & still get the game. I've definitely had a ton of fun & still enjoy the game!

So, if you're more of an objective gamer & really wanna make sure your purchase is worth it, do not buy Chivalry II in its current state. Even gesturing at its current state, I'm skeptical if there's really any hope for improvement though, considering the game released in June of 2021 (Two whole years ago as of writing) & yet it has the issues it has.

It's inexcusable that in a competitive game like this, this far out from release, your playerbase is still  frequently & randomly experiencing a glitch where one will not respawn after dying in the middle of a match. Typically, one will see a 5-15 second countdown to respawning after dying. Unfortunately, one will frequently encounter an inability to respawn, having died & being left to only spectate for the remainder of the match.

Research online suggests that many others experience this issue, some reporting that they'll respawn after waiting 8+ minutes, suiciding (F10, sometimes multiple times), or by switching teams after getting stuck. Waiting 8+ minutes, even just 1-2 minutes is absurd in itself but also when considering how thoroughly one is impacting a match while effectively being benched for that long. Suiciding negatively affects your score and doesn't seem to work most of the times I've tried, sometimes suiciding 5+ times to no avail. Switching teams, you either can't in a full lobby, or will feasibly give up & lose a slot on a winning team.

The only truly reliable way to get around it is to leave the match, wipe the scoreboard, and hope that slot is still waiting for you on the way back in. Got 34 kills & only 3 deaths? Sorry buddy, if you want to respawn, you're gonna have to set that back to 0 & 0 for me real quick.

In addition to that issue, which can really ruin the high of doing well in a match, there's a stuttering problem that the playerbase has been experiencing. In a game where the visuals you can perceive within a fraction of a second tells you whether to block or swing to win a fight, sudden freeze frames & frame skips (stuttering) can frequently land you headless when you were certain you made the correct input 0.8 seconds ago.

Thankfully, there is a fix for this issue, conveniently explained in a video by Ziggylata on YT:
 - Chivalry 2 Update Stutter fix (On PC)

This fix basically involves going into your games files & deleting a file. While it's an available solution, and does work (from experience) it's another absurd issue to have this far out from release & when considering just how important visuals are here compared to something like XCOM 2 or Civ VI.

That concludes my review, fingers crossed they fix these issues some day.
Thanks for reading!

This is a beautiful game. The choreographed battle scenarios make this feel like the equivalent of the Battle of The Bastards, combined with Narnia and a little inspiration from the Lord of The Rings. They even have role swaps to make you play as the peasantry in some parts to show the beginnings of a medieval raid, then to introduce the knights and soldiers to come to their aid. Weapons are balanced between classes so there's not a large difference in advantages, and you find matches in just about 3 seconds. Include a battle pass system that has no timer and is introduced organically into the game to add to progression content, and you have a fantastic experience that makes you feel like you're in the frontlines of the elite. 

This game is so much more than what I was expecting.
