The negative reviews about this being a steamroll simulator are true. If you're looking for a fair, competitive experience where a skilled player can carry and turn the tide, this isn't it.

I figured out very quickly that Chivalry 2 was unfair, unbalanced, unconcerned with status, and unconcerned with whether individual skill is given room to change the outcome of a battle. Players can freely swap teams to get out of a losing situation and start kicking their old team in the teeth. If you find yourself in a 1v1 and hold your own for a bit, the enemy will ignore everyone else on your team to single out the distracted guy fending off his death, and jam a free spear into his undefended, unbaptized bits. Sometimes a catapult just obliterates you for 2550 damage with no hope of counterplay.

This is a big dumb meatgrinder where you beat other players bloody with swords and hammers, to unlock more swords and hammers. You run in and die, repeat, and every bit of the game's design acknowledges that it's meant to be this way. You even respawn freely at a full sprint and are equipped with loud, hammy, extremely-committed battle cries.

And you know what? I could cry tears of f-cking joy that they still make multiplayer games like this. It doesn't care about being esport material where celebrity-hopefuls have a ladder to climb, or whether it's watchable on stream. 

It's betting every dollar it has on the idea that if it hands you a warhammer and lets you flatten Brave Ser XxKushSniper69xX like a soda can, then you, the player, will be having carefree, selfish fun... and then it gives you 31 other knights to try and clobber, because that's 31x as much fun. Yeah, it's messy, but I have so much fun just trying to bonk the guy in front of me that I don't care at all who wins, I'm just glad to have fresh skulls to crush.

Yes, you'll almost always see one team losing badly to the other, even on something as unstructured as an open-ground team TDM battle. It's okay to be bothered by this, but personally I don't mind this even when it's my turn in the washing machine full of knives. I find this adds drama and a personal element to these matches, where it's much more satisfying to send a plate helmet clattering across the floor when it belonged to a complacent knight that thought everyone on my team would go down so easily... 

...this goes doubly for when you corner one of those much-hated archers, where they'll either win back some small dignity by putting up a decent scrap with their backup weapon, or die shamefully with a bow in their hands and piss in their grieves. There's just something about swinging a cannonball of a mace into to an enemy that's EARNED your wrath.

A couple more quick pros: as implied earlier, there's a progression/unlock system to offer you more options as you play, and the melee system is great, even if it translates kinda predictably over the net. Maps are ASTONISHINGLY gorgeous with some of the most beautiful mosques and churches I've seen in a game, and they rotate quickly without much downtime; everything about this game is constantly pushing you back into the fight for another reckless charge.

Overall, 10/10 for dumb multiplayer fun. I wish more online games were confident enough to implement a fun, simple concept and be content to let the damn thing breathe.

[h1]Chivalry II[/h1]

[h3]Summary:[/h3]
This game is the pinnacle of medieval combat. Fight in a war, desecrate a relic, kill pagan religious leaders, abduct peasants and pigs, decapitate an archer who didn't respect your greatsword, blow up trebuchets, kick people off bridges, commit regicide, get launched out of a catapult, kill someone with bread. If you believe it could exist in the medieval combat setting, you can probably achieve it in this game. With combat presented in 3rd or 1st person, and a complex but fair control orientation, the grueling lows of getting absolutely destroyed in 1-on-1 combat are completely erased by seeing heads, arms, legs and everything between go flying as you mow through the enemy forces. The boards are incredibly detailed, with huge intricate stories interwoven into the game play directly. 

[h3]Pros:[/h3]
The game is a pure spectacle of gore and violence, and allows for the player to be completely engaged with that as up close and personally as they desire. The combat presents a complex, fast paced rock-paper-scissors type countering game that has easy work-arounds through either positioning, feints, or the well timed kick. The game has an absolutely humongous weapon set, with everything locked behind progression, which feels spectacular. The cosmetics are also largely available through progression alone, which provides for a very satisfying capacity to customize the presentation of each character. The classes and sub-classes, with their own distinct weapon sets and progressions provides consistent engagement with the larger progression based meta-game, while still improving their distinct paths in fun and unique manners. 

[h3]Cons:[/h3]
The party management/UI is terrible and buggy as shit. The menus are also wonky as hell if you're playing on a controller and have a mouse and keyboard active. The game crashes constantly when its closing, but it doesn't seem to affect game play at all. Cross-play between steam/xbox game pass is doable, but limited, which feels bad. The game doesn't have DLSS turned on as a standard option, so for higher end optimization, check that in the settings. 

[h3]Overall Score: 8.5/10[/h3]
Buy this while its on sale, its well worth the money.

Chivalry 2 is the perfect game for those who have always wanted to live out their medieval battle fantasies, but without the threat of actual injury... unless you count the emotional scars from losing a joust to your best friend.

In Chivalry 2, you can swing your sword with wild abandon, charge into battle with a battle cry that would make William Wallace proud, and participate in epic siege battles that would make Game of Thrones' Battle of Winterfell look like a schoolyard scuffle.

But be warned, the learning curve is steep, and you may find yourself on the receiving end of a mace to the face more times than you care to admit. But don't worry, your virtual squire will be there to revive you, ready to charge into battle once again!

So grab your favorite medieval weapon and prepare to join the fight in Chivalry 2, where honor and glory (and a few hilarious glitches) await!

Chivalry 2 is a wild ride of medieval mayhem. The combat system is easy to pick up, but the challenge lies in mastering it, and of course - chopping off your enemies' limbs has never been so satisfying. The maps are beautifully done and provide the perfect backdrop for all the gore and bodies. Game is still fun to play even in 2023. Developers are always keeping the game fresh with events and updates. It's the ultimate hack-and-slash simulator and I'm satisfied. If you're looking for a good laugh and some intense combat, Chivalry 2 is the game for you!

Although with a few bugs and some trolls on the public servers, this is an amazing medieval fighting game that both tests your skill and patience. Easy to get into, but demands months of practice - followed by continuous "attendance" to become truly skillful. I still suck at this game, but seeing how I slowly become better is part of the joy. I do not regret this purchase.
